conversation.Rottin Wood: Hunter’s greeting! I assume you want something from me since you came all the way out here on your own. This is a dangerous place to be, I doubt that all my men will accept strangers like I do. You don’t seem to have any problems with that, though.
My name is Rottin Wood, I’m the leader of this bunch – but hey, everyone knows that, right? Right.
We are hunters. We are chasing our prey in the woods, ever watchful, ever deadly, evergreen.

Aaaaah the thrill of the hunt. The wind in the forest making the trees talk to you. The glistening water of the rivers and lakes… you cannot get enough of it, can you? OUCH! Fir cone… again… I hate this… ah, nevermind.
Isn’t it a beautiful world? Just look at this forest, aaah.
Well, he never tells anyone his real name. He always wears his old wedding ring, though. It has a small engraving, the letters ‘H.’ and ‘L.’. So we simply call him H.L.
Yes, we were all married once. In fact we still are. That’s why we’re here. …

We are selling lucky charms. Actually each lucky charm is an ordinary rabbit’s foot – with a special handcrafted ribbon of course, heh. Made by the guys, heh. The people in Thais are going crazy for those.
I don’t like the city. I sleep among trees out in the open.
Carlin? Never been there.
Been there once, but that was a long time ago.
I’m the king of the forest.
I command my own… army. And I’m proud to say that we are the… the strongest – hey, hey you there, are you taking a nap?! You’re on sentry duty! Quit fooling around and start your shift!
Judging by the position of the sun, the wind in the trees, the slightly glistening dew on the moss and my watch – it is about 2:38 am.
What? That old legend? If you want legends, you should join us – unfortunately it isn’t possible for you to join us. In fact, no one can, heh.
Yeah, well. I’m the king of the forest – what about that, eh?
Hey there, well no new missions from Rottin Wood and his men today – but you can still help us with some tasks.
Some random fool came here and started getting on everyone’s nerves. Oh wait, you’re HERE. Hmph.
Alright of course. You can help us getting even more lucky charms. There are also some repairs to be made around the camp. For now these are the only tasks we can offer.

Are you ready to get more lucky charms? You know, if we won’t get our hands on new charms in time, we will surely have to starve… during the autumn. That would be a hard time for all of us. So… you in once again?
Welcome back, did you repair all the broken structures?
If you don’t want to do this – I have no problem with that. But my comrades… well if they are getting a cold, have fun getting out of the woods in one piece.

Are you ready to get more lucky charms? You know, if we won’t get our hands on new charms in time, we will surely have to starve… during the autumn. That would be a hard time for all of us. So… you in once again?

Hey, I like rabbits too, alright? And I doubt anyone would even notice if you would just take a wooden spoon and put some wool on it with the ribbon. But the people want it – and we need the money. So, no pain, no gain, my friend.
Not possible. You cannot – in fact no one can – join us. Not anymore. …

Hmmm. I buy weapons, armor, and other stuff. What do you want, Player?
Elves… I hate them.
Forget the gods
Women are not good for fighting. I don’t need them. I don’t trade with them. And I don’t like them.
Well Snake Eye isn’t ‘my’ boss if you mean that.
Hmmm. Let me think. I guess you need something big. And steel-reinforced. A barrel, maybe.
You mean our old building in the south-west?
Ah, nevermind.
That’s the old hideout. Quite an interesting place down there. There are lots of security mechanics and traps. But it collapsed partly.
Yes. That’s why we… well, they planned a new hideout. Our old hideout was the original vault.
There might be still some good stuff in there, I guess.
You mean inside that vault? Uhm. I don’t know what stuff there is. Sorry.
I don’t have anything to offer, but I buy almost everything. Wanna trade?
I buy weapons, distance weapons, armors and shields. If you want to see only a certain category, tell me which of those.
Ha! Thais. I lived there once. You know, I was in the royal army. But what they’re fighting for… it’s all wrong. I deserted.
You get an excellent fighter training in the army. But they are fighting for the wrong cause.
I don’t really want to talk about it.
Forget about Cip.
Wild warriors always have something to hide.
What key? Show me!
Oh. That’s a new key. Hmmm. Must be for the new hideout.
Yes. Those doors seem to be driven by some strange… devices. But I have no idea how they work. Maybe you can find something out?
Yeah. I’m a wild warrior. Well, to be honest, I was. I left them. Some of them became too aggressive. Simply attacking everyone for no reason is not good.
Dwarfs are good people. I like them.
Forget Durin. He’s the worst anyway.
Forget Steve.
Forget Guido.
Forget Stephan.
Might be a good place to live. But the people are too Thais friendly for my taste
That’s me.
They should hang him…
I buy all kinds of armory and weapons.
Well, at least there’s one place worth visiting in Tibia. Here!
Won’t tell you.
It’s somewhere in the woods, of course. I don’t know where.
Most people in the camp are just hunters.
Tibia doesn’t need a ruler.
He the boss of that tavern. He’s alright.
About what? I have no time for this, now move along.
Didn’t I already tell you to go? If you don’t have anything important to say, leave me alone.
Be careful out there.
You can drink and eat there. Everything you want in a tavern.
These woods are a good place to hide.
Bye.

conversation.Snake Eye: Hi Player. Come in and have a drink.
I can offer you beer and wine. Ask me for a trade.
Of course, just browse through my wares.
Well, I’m the boss of this tavern.
I’m Snake Eye.
He is a wild warrior. Nobody knows his real name. We just call him H.L. You can find him in the small armory shop.
He’s the worst. The so called god of the dwarves. I don’t believe it. It’s all crap.
Never heard of him.
Never heard of him.
Never heard of him.
Cip sux!
Well, I had a dispute with a snake once. And the snake won. Bit my left eye out. Therefore, Snake Eye.
It’s a great tavern. No closing time. No problems with kings or other rulers. Best place in Tibia.
Yeah. I’m the boss. So don’t bother me.
There’s already too much order in Tibia. We don’t need kings or whatever.
We don’t need one.
Go and get a watch.
Believe me! There are no gods.
The Gods of Tibia! What a crap! It’s all superstition!
Crap. Crap! CRAP! It’s all CRAP!
In the beginning, it was a nice encampment. Now it’s an overcrowded, polluted city. I hate it!
I’ve never been there. Don’t know anything about it.
Kazordoon is alright. Except for the dwarves. I don’t like them. But the mountains are a good place. Been there once.
That’s a place for wealthy toffs!
I’ve never been there. I don’t like the elves anyway.
There are a lot of wild warriors around. They built this camp.
Well, the real wild warriors don’t live here. They hide in the woods.
Well. I know of a small camp to the south.
It’s abandoned. But I bet that something is hidden there!
Go and find out yourself. You can tell me if you find something.
It’s the best place to live. By the way, there’s an old wild warrior building to the southwest. It might be interesting for you.
Go and ask H.L. about it.
It’s abandoned. But I bet that something is hidden there!

conversation.The Crone: I don’t remember my name, neither my days as a mortal.
Once I was Vashresamun’s favourite handmaid. But I have fallen from grace and now I’m exiled from her tomb.
Don’t ask about it, mortal. Memories bring too much grief.
I mourn the dark day I was exiled from her tomb.
Her tomb is sealed and can only be entered with a certain melody.
Vashresamun erased the memory of the tune from my mind, I only remember its name: The Secret of the Rose Garden.

conversation.Melchior: Greetings, Player. I do not see your face, but I can read a thousand things in your voice!
I am a poor beggar. I try to make a meagre living here since a cruel fate has left me a blind man.
Yes, I am. I was not born that way, but a cruel fate caused me to lose my eyesight.
Fate played a cruel trick on old Melchior. If you want me to, I can tell you my story – talking about one’s grievances does help to ease the pain. So – would you like to hear my story?

While my eyes were still of use to me I worked as a trader. I was not too successful, so I started looking for alternatives. Remembering some old nomad legends I went to explore the Kha’zeel. If only I’d never done that! …
After many days I met a weird creature – it was humanoid, but it was also much larger than any man, and it seemed to be only half-solid in a way. …
I was scared, but I remembered my grandfather’s stories and I hailed the creature using the traditional djinn word of greeting. …

It worked. I managed to engage the djinn – for it was one sure enough – in a conversation. In fact, I even managed to come to an agreement with it. The djinns living there needed supplies, and I promised I would bring them some. …
A highly profitable business relationship ensued. Unfortunately, my greed grew every day, and it clouded my sense of judgement. …
Hearing that there was a second djinn fortress I travelled there. Those djinn, who called themselves the Marid, were friendly enough, and soon I traded with them as well. …
Unfortunately, it did not take the other djinn tribe, the Efreet, long to find out what I was up to. …
The Efreets’ punishment was cruel: They blinded me and left me in the Kha’labal to die of thirst and exhaustion as food for the scarabs. But that was a favour I could not do them. …
I desperately struggled on and finally I was picked up by a caravan. They took me here, and now I am sort of stuck here in this city of the half-dead.
The djinns are a wondrous race. Swift and strong they are and larger, much larger than any man. …

And yet, djinns fit into tiny lamps, for they are but half solid creatures who can change into mist whenever they want to! It is as though they lived between the worlds, travelling hither and thither as they please. …
Little is known about their origin, but legend has it Zathroth himself, the dark master of magic, created them to some unknown evil purpose. …

But they are not evil, and perhaps that is why Zathroth eventually abandoned them! Djinns have independent minds and souls just like humans, and just like us they are forlorn creatures struggling to find their place in creation. …
They have fought a bitter, bitter war between themselves over this, a cataclysmic war that led them to the brink of self-destruction. …
Today they are few and far between, but they are still divided into two warring factions, the gentle Marid and the cruel Efreet, and neither side will rest until the other is utterly defeated. …
If you ever meet a djinn make sure to say the word of greeting immediately. Otherwise he will simply ignore you or worse – if it is an Efreet he will kill you outright. …
And remember, once you decided to follow one group of djinns you can never switch sides, so choose well. No Efreet will ever deal with a follower of the Marid and vice versa.

The Marid are gentle, kind-hearted djinn, or at least that is how they act towards humans. However, they are quite reclusive, too. They will not talk to human unless he says the word of greeting first. …
And do not approach them if you are a follower of the Efreet – they are impossible to fool!

Beware the Efreet, stranger! They hate all humans, and if they had their way all of us would be killed. If you meet one be sure to say the word of greeting immediately because otherwise you will be killed in a heartbeat. …
And do not approach them if you are a follower of the Marid – they are impossible to fool!
The pharaoh? He is always in the palace, so I have heard only rumors about him. But I know one thing for sure – he is mad. End of story.
Fate played a cruel trick on old Melchior. If you want me to, I can tell you my story – talking about one’s grievances does help to ease the pain. So – would you like to hear my story?
As you wish, stranger.
Tibia is such a beautiful place. I would give it all if I could see it again.

I hate this city. Period. I would never have come here, but I haven’t had much of a choice. The caravan that picked me up in the Kha’zeel was headed for this place, and I was glad enough they brought me here. …
But now I really wish I could leave. <whispers> These people and their ruler give me the creeps!
That is my name.
Ah yes – I recognise that. According to the pharaoh that is a living being’s soul.
According to the pharaoh’s teachings this is the total of a living being’s memories and personal experiences.
Ah yes, the arena. I do not really know what’s going on there, because I have never seen it myself. However, I often hear strange noises from there, cheers and jeers and sometimes pitiful screams.
<Sighs> Aah yes… Darashia. I would give anything if I could see it again.

conversation.Melchior: I have never been to cities on other continents. And I suppose now I never will. I would be glad enough to leave this place.
Spare me that inane twaddle, will you? I am glad enough to be alive, thank you.
That temple is very old, and for centuries it used to be a place of worship and of contemplation. Now that the priests there are fanatic followers of the pharaoh, it is no longer a holy place.

The palace lies to the south of the arena and to the west of the temple. Better stay clear of that place. If but half the things I have heard about it are true this palace is not a place for the living anymore.
That is the name of the huge mountain range to the west of the great desert, the Kha’labal. That’s where you will find the djinns’ fortresses Ashta’daramai and Mal’ouquah. …

They say it was created by the gods as a vantage point from which they used watch their creation. I think it is true. I used to travel there often, and I swear I often felt the presence of something special, something… divine.
Aaaah… The great desert. Legend has it that in ancient times it was a beautiful garden. I don’t know if that is true, but I must admit I love it just the way it is. …
Travelling through that endless stretch of barren land always gave me a very special peace of mind.
Aah yes – the Marids’ fortress. Perched high on the Kha’zeel, it is a marvel to behold. They say Gabel built it on the ruins of his original palace.

He is the leader of the Marid! I have never met him myself, but everybody was full of praise for him back at Ashta’daramai. The legend has it that it was him who introduced the djinns to wise Daraman’s teachings.

Daraman was a holy man, a true prophet. He showed us how we can master grief and affliction through dignity and brotherliness. It is a shame I only came to fully appreciate his teachings when fate had cast me into darkness.
Malor is the Efreets’ leader. He is perhaps not the strongest of all efreet, but his treachery and cruelty are certainly unrivalled. He was defeated a long, long time ago, but he was not killed. …
I don’t know why… I have a strange feeling of foreboding whenever I hear his name.
My late father, may he rest in peace, chose to call me Melchior.
I know that name. He is a Marid. This djinn is one of the best smiths ever to live. You should see the scimitars he makes – hard as titanium yet light as a desert breeze. …
I kept on trying to get the Marid to sell one to me, but they never did. Too bad – I could have made a fortune.
Those damn scavengers! I detest them. When I was stumbling through the desert, all blind and desperate, they followed me around. …
They watched my every step, waiting for me to give up and die. But I never did. Damn vermin! You’ll have to eat somebody else!
I know that name. He is a Marid, right? I have met him once. He seemed pretty important.
Cursed be that djinn! It was him who blinded me, and I bet casting me out into the Kha’labal was his idea, too. Believe me, I would try to kill him if only I could.

A Marid trader. I have often had dealings with him. He drove me mad because he never accepted any haggling, but then he never ever tried to trick me. He was not really a trader at heart, I suppose. He was more of a monk or maybe a preacher.

Yes, I know him. He is an Efreet trader. I met him often during my travels, and even though there was no real sympathy we had a certain mutual respect for each other. But all that changed when he found out I had dealings with the Marid.
The old pharaoh? I keep on hearing rumours about him, but I do not know if they are true.
The concept of ascension is central to the pharaoh’s creed. I am not sure I really understand it, but apparently it has to do with transformation to undeath. Nice, isn’t it?
In the pharaoh’s creed, this is what the physical body is called.
He is a cook – a djinn cook. A weird guy. Always used to ask me to procure some strange kind of ingredient or other for him. …
He made me laugh. Can you imagine what that looks like – a djinn wearing an enormous chef hat?
I know that name. He is a Marid, right? I have met him once. He seemed pretty important.

That is the Efreet’s gloomy fortress, home of Malor, hidden high up in the Kha’zeel mountains. I used to go there often. Don’t make the same mistake, stranger! I would love to think there is somebody who profited from the lesson I had to learn!
Farewell, stranger. May Uman the Wise guide your steps in this treacherous land.

conversation.Tothdral: Be mourned Player, pilgrim in flesh. If you’re here for sorcerer spells or to trade, be welcome.

The great suffering is a phase of steady decline that will end eventually in void and emptiness unless some divine power such as our pharaoh will reverse it. Mend your ways and follow him! Perhaps you will be chosen to join him in his noble struggle.
Undeath alone will rid you of the temptations that blur your vision of the true path.
You can give me relics of the false gods. They need to be destroyed before they do more harm than they’ve already caused by making people believe in lies.
My name is Tothdral. They call me ‘The Seeker Beyond the Grave’.
This city is as old as the sands that surround it, and it is built on previous settlements that date back even further in time. Perhaps only the wise scarabs know the full story of this place.
If you know how to listen to them they will reveal ancient secrets to you.
Those cities that bow to the false gods will fall prey to their treacherous greed sooner or later.
Elves are nothing but idle riff-raff. They embrace the vain amusements of physical pleasure. Eternal damnation will be their lot.
Their foolishness is great, but perhaps they still can be saved. If only they listened and accepted the next step to ascension.

The essence of the true gods is omnipresent in the universe. We all share this divine heritage, for every single one of us carries the divine spark inside him. This is the reason we all have a chance to ascend to godhood, too.

The self-styled gods were nothing but minor servants of the true gods. They steal the soul of any mortal foolish enough to believe in them. They plan to use the stolen souls to ascend to true godhood.
The Akh’rah Uthun is the trinity of existence, the three that are one. The Akh, the shell, the Rah, the source of power, and the Uthun, our consciousness, form this union.
The Akh is a tool. As long as it is alive it is a burden and source of weakness, but if you ascend to undeath it becomes a useful tool that can be used to work towards greater ends.
The Rah is what the ignorant might call the soul. But it’s more than that. It is the divine spark in all of us, the source of energy that keeps us alive.

The Uthun is the part of the trinity that is easiest to form. It consists of our recollections of the past and of our thoughts. It is that which determines who we are in this world and it gives us guidance throughout our existence.
This world is only a shadow of the worlds that have been. That was long ago, before the true gods fought each other in the godwars and the false gods rose to claim their heritage.
This continent is mostly free from the servants of the false gods. Those who live here may hope to become worthy one day of the first steps towards ascension.
Undeath is an improvement. It is the gateway to goals that are nobler than eating, drinking or other fulfilments of trivial physical needs.
I am the foremost astrologer and supreme magus of this city.
The immortal pharaoh is our god and our example. He alone holds the secrets that will save us all from the greedy grasp of the false gods.
Time is your problem. It is no longer mine.
Mortality is your curse. When you are worthy the burden of mortality will be taken from your shoulders.
Our temple is a centre of spirituality and learning. The temple and the serpentine tower work hand in hand for the good of all people, whether they are alive or undead.
The dead mourn the living because they are weak and excluded from ascension.

This war brought about the end of the true universe. That which is left now is but a shadow of former glories, a bleak remainder of what once was. The true gods perished and their essence was dispersed throughout the remaining universe.
The arena is a suitable distraction for the Uthun of the mortals. It might even serve as a place for them to prove their worth. If they pass the test they may be freed of their mortal shells.
The residence of the pharaoh should be worshipped just as the pharaoh is worshipped. Don’t enter until you have business there.
Strive for enlightenment, mourned mortal Player.

conversation.An Ancient Priest: Greetings mortal! What brings you here? I have a job to do you know.
I’m the caretaker of this tomb. I also know these parts like the back of my hand – just in case you need a status update.
I preserve the history of the great Pharaoh Horestis.
He was one of the first Pharaohs of the united tribes and under his rule the race of man flourished to formerly unknown heights.
Horestis’s body has been desecrated. His curse now hangs over the land like the shadow of the vulture. Abandon all hope mortals, his vengeance will be dreadful.
He wisely used the power of his position to unite the tribes of the desert who formerly defied the rules of the dynasty.
The ancestors of the dynasty led the human tribes from the lizard-ruled jungles to the desert where they could finally live without prosecution.
In the jungle the cruel lizards hunted humans for sport and although food was abundant, the humans were denied any hunting grounds as the lizards claimed everything for themselves.
The lizards were powerful and many. They wielded magic unknown to the race of man at this time. Nothing could oppose their rule in these days. …
The desert was harsh but avoided by the lizards. Due to cunning and resilience the humans prevailed where the lizards had failed.
They learned to live with that little that the desert and the sea had to offer. They dwelt in the caves of the mountains, however, some split and rather roamed the desert.
The caves were the first safe haven of humankind since the beginning of time. They were widened and artificial caves were added. …
Even later when a settlement had been built at the coast, the caves served as final retreat and fortress in times of danger.

Some defied the rules of the dynasty that had made the jungle of Tiquanda taboo for all humans. When they wandered into the jungle to hunt and steal equipment and secrets about the desert, they provoked punishing raids by the lizard people.
The raids were a great danger for the tribes of man in these days. They had not the manpower or weapons to stand against the might of the lizards.
Only slowly the humans became a power on their own. They learned from the desert, they learned from its inhabitants and finally, they learned how to communicate with its spirits.
The spirits of nature and of the animals began to talk to selected individuals. Individuals that used forbidden arts derived from what had been stolen from the lizards.
In the jungle, the humans had learned some of the most basic principles of magic through observation and experimentation. …
Although everything connected with the lizard was seen as tainted, many of the greatest minds turned their attention to those studies.
The first shamans of mankind wielded only little power and there was only a small distinction between magic and making fire or creating a tool. …
But when their dabbling with magic brought them into connection with the spirit world it became a breakthrough.

The spirits talked to the shamans and taught them many new things. The rock revealed its secrets and taught the humans to build with stone and to melt ore to metal. The water taught them about the places where to find it and how to conserve it. …
The scorpion taught the use of poison and medicine, explained how to craft an armor and told them much about warfare. Many more spirits revealed their secrets, big and small.
With the emergence of these secrets, the shamans came out of hiding and boldly rose to power. Fights ensued and only the most mighty would prevail as leaders.
The most powerful shaman and fighter became the chieftain and the others became priests under his rule. …
The chieftain married only into the families of priests and soon the first dynasty emerged.
When the dynasty emerged, the chieftains were called Pharaohs. They were the absolute rulers on this side of the mountains. Soon the caves were abandoned and people left for fortified settlements.
When the caves were abandoned, Horestis ordered to rebuild them into a temple and a tomb at once.
Wide parts of the caves were planned to become a temple where the spirits of nature could be worshipped. …
It served as spiritual centre of the realm and Horestis’s tomb was an integral part of the complex.
For a few generations after Horestis’s death, the complex has been used as planned by the Pharaoh. …
Then the interest in the old spirits waned and new rulers embraced more sinister secrets …
Those were stolen and traded from the lizards and gained by bargains with the envious and reclusive scarab spirit. …
The spirits turned more and more away from the humans and the humans turned away from the spirits. So the old pact had been broken.
The spirits, the temple and the tomb became forgotten. …

A few of the remaining priests, loyal to the pact, exiled themselves to the complex and summoned vengeful spirits as guardians of the tomb and the temple and they constructed several protections to ensure that Horestis’s eternal rest is not disturbed.
Many of the protections faded away over the centuries. …
A few of the most powerful remain though. Foremost there are the spirits and guardians of the temple that will fight every intruder. …
But their might is bound to the tomb and if Horestis’s rest is disturbed, they will eventually fade away. The tomb itself is sealed with the help of Horestis’ canopic jars. …
As long as the canopic jars are intact, the tomb is sealed against any intruder. Also Horestis’s honour guards keep watch. …
If Horestis’s body will ever be desecrated, they will rise from the desert to take revenge upon the living. Vast armies of undead warriors will seek revenge and try to strike down the living. …
Finally there is Horestis’s scorpion curse. He was the high priest of the scorpion spirit and his scorpions will spawn, particularly from the bodies of scarabs.
The canopic jars contain the preserved organs of Horestis’s mummified body. …
They are powerful magic talismans that ward off any intrusion into Horestis’s tomb.
Farewell, mortal.

conversation.Messenger of Heaven: Greetings, Player! It's good to see you alive.
With the world in peril, everyone's life is at stake.
The actions of Ferumbras and the sinister minions of the thing from beyond have shattered the world. The thing is worming its way into our reality and its workings will cause further damage.
To name it is to give it power. Even to think about it gives it a hold. But it can't be helped and now that it is entering our world it doesn't worsen the matter significantly. ...
Yet, thinking about it might call for its attention and might give it a hold upon you. At least that was the case in the past.
Through history several of those who were too curious became aware of its existence - or better its lack. They were touched and tainted by the knowledge. ...

It is assumed that the ancient Yalahari were the first to really grasp at least part of the concept of what it is. This knowledge gave it a tremendous hold over the Yalahari's minds and it even gave it a name.
Names hold power. The gods called things into existence by naming them. By giving something a name, it becomes more real. Ideas become concepts, feelings become expressible and so on. ...
In the case of the thing that wasn't, the name gave it a hold on reality, gave it a glimpse at our world. By naming it, the Yalahari began to understand it, in a twisted way at least. ...
A knowledge that was twisted in itself and twisted the minds of those who knew. At last, the Yalahari vanished from the world and even the gods don't know their fate for sure. ...

Now that this thing - which was not meant to be - entered our world, its name might be old news, so to say. However, it's still dangerous and malignant, nothing to be spoken or thought of lightly, especially not by you mortals.
Probably his vain plea for ascension has brought upon him a fate worse than hell.
While the thing becomes more real, it sheds layers of destruction and negligence of reality. Those layers are becoming threats on their own. ...

They eat away matter as well as laws of nature. They are threatening the creation as a whole. Even without doing anything more than becoming more and more real, the thing might win by simply undoing creation. This has to be stopped!

The destruction that comes with that thing shares the intention of its progenitor to become more real. Therefore, the destruction has gathered into something that - under other circumstances - would be called avatars. ...
Some destructive and unnatural forces have condensed themselves to highly dangerous constructs that are gnawing at existence itself. Even now their workings can be felt. ...

All over the world incursions like this one here can be encountered. They eat away matter, sanity and order - sucking them into nothingness. Behind these incursions, on the brink to nothingness and annihilation, the non-avatars are lurking. ...
Their most potent incarnation has been named Heart of Destruction. But there are others - less potent but disruptive on their own. The heart gives those mindless forces unity and purpose. ...
It unites them to the threat that they are. Every incursion itself it only restricted to time and space. Reality will eventually heal and recover, although not for an unlimited amount of time. ...
It is the heart what makes them so dangerous and gives them drive. Under the hunger and anger of the Heart of Destruction, the incursions are more potent and reality is breaking. ...
To stop them from devouring reality, the destruction has to be stopped by destroying its heart.

You will notice many incursions throughout the world. They are accompanied by waves of uncreated beings. By killing them, you weaken the incursion which they are part of. Yet, you will get tainted with their disruptive nature. ...

A person of strong will might resist the taint and even use it to enter the incursions. Beyond them awaits only a thin layer of ... let's call it yet undigested reality in which the non-avatars nest. ...
Each incursion, aside from similarities, hosts another of those things. All of them are kin to their source, the Heart of Destruction. ...
If you manage to destroy one of them, a part of its ungodly charge will be passed upon you. Again you might be able to use that to your advantage, though. ...

If you manage to slay the different masters of the greater incursions, you'll eventually blend in with their disruptive nature and might venture further into the incursions and challenge the heart itself. ...

But even getting to the masters of the incursions will not be an easy task. Each of them will be guarded by some kind of instinctive reaction that will have to be dealt with before you might advance to the incursion's master.
One can only call this thing the world devourer. It eats away reality and feeds on the world itself. ...
The thing is as unfathomable as the thing that spawned it. It is doubtful that its creation was an act of will. Regardless it is the utmost threat that we face right now. ...

As long as the world devourer exists, the healing powers of reality will not suffice to contain the damage caused by the incursions. Likely sooner than later reality and its laws will begin to break. ...
The thing itself is nothing anyone has ever encountered yet. Its existence alone is an anathema to creation and is hurting the world. ...

It's something between existence and destruction, between force and creature. Its whole existence is a paradox itself and harmful to the world. We have no idea how it works or what are its weaknesses. ...
It will take a keen mind to figure this out and a strong heart and soul to endure the perils on the way.
Your future is still not written because the forces of uncreation are still tearing on reality. For the sake of your world, please hurry!

I think Mr. West is planning to take over the whole city, if it hasn’t been destroyed by war, contamination, monsters or greater evil by then.
I will never ever go there, and if I were sent there, I’d resign from the Guard Force.
This city contains so much evil that I fear one day it will explode and end up in chaos and darkness.
Goodbye citizen!

conversation.Dorbin: Hello, Player! Welcome to my furniture store. I hope you are interested in a trade!
I’m Dorbin.
I sell furniture. We own this store in the third generation.

conversation.Maritima: Oh hello, visitor from the dry land.
I’m a mermaid. I sing songs and play with the fishes.

Some centuries ago, the Yalahari used to visit the bottom of the ocean. Then all of a sudden, their visits ended.

conversation.Gree Dee: Be greeted esteemed customer with a full purse!
I sell general equipment. Just ask me for a trade.
You will not believe how cheap my items are.
My foolish brother thinks he’ll get rich by selling equipment to some inexperienced paupers, but I know better!
Just ask me for a trade.

The city is a virtual gold mine. People from all over the world come here to explore and to get rich …
So they have much money to spend on supplies!
They aren’t worse than other nobles or officials. To be precise, they are so uninterested in our affairs that I prefer them to other city officials.
Uhm, unfortunately I just ran out of garlic necklaces. But I heard they help.
I’m not interested in trading my wares for cookies.
If they ever rebuild that city, I really hope to participate in this venture in some way.
If you find some treasures down there, I might be interested in doing business with you.
I tried to convince them of the quality of human wares, but without success.
I think the Yalahari should leave the factories inactive. They’d only ruin honest people’s profit.
Mr. West is a honest man, that’s for sure. You’ll never hear me saying something bad about Mr. West.
The surviving magicians there seem to rely on resources they get by themselves. What a shame!
I wonder where these gladiators get their supplies from? I wouldn’t mind to sell them some decent equipment.
If I had one, I could charge a fortune for it… <gets a dreamy look>
My shop will be famous soon enough. With all the dangers that are around this city, adventurers have to resupply constantly!
You really should have bought some extra stuff, just in case.

conversation.Peter: Hello. Unless you have official business here or want to pass the gate, please move on.

Good idea. Go for a walk there. Preferably six feet down.
Go there if you wanna get beaten up.
Sergeant first class of the Yalaharian Guard Force. But I don’t care about ranks and titles.
I can’t stand those arrogant fools.
Leave me alone with your ‘mission’ unless you have precise orders from my superiors.

conversation.Palimuth: Greetings.
I’m an Augur of the city of Yalahar. My special duty consists of coordinating the efforts to keep the city and its services running.
I’m Palimuth. Nice to meet you.
I’m a bit worried about our city’s current state!
It is a somewhat futile mission but I won’t give up.
I’m afraid we have not seen the last chapter of Yalahar’s drama but I don’t have any more missions for you.
Yes, that is indeed a threat. Those raids, not knowing who to trust… unfortunately that matter lies not in my hands.
The Yalahari are up to something strange and it does not bode well for the city of Yalahar!
As if Yalahar had not already endured enough hardship, also nature seemed to have conspired to ruin the city. It was a great disaster when a large part of the city simply broke away.
The people there are rather desperate than evil. Still the quarter poses a danger, especially for strangers.
Once, the Yalahari had the policy that their city is open for everyone who comes here in peace. Considering the situation in the foreign quarter today, they seem to have changed this policy. …
I can’t blame them. Still, I wonder if there is no hope for a peaceful coexistence.
As annoying it might be for my superiors, the presence of Mr. West and his private army of bullies brings at least some sort of order for a great part of our townspeople.
The Yalahari seem to be quite interested in retaking this quarter. But all efforts ended in the loss of men, they could not even nearly replace.
We did little to retake the arena quarter. On the one hand, we lack the manpower, on the other hand, it turned into some sort of food resource for the city.
There are no more addons available for you at this time.
Well, Azerus Vilus wasn’t a high-ranking Yalahari in the past. Something must have happened which gained him so much power. …
Still, I can’t imagine anybody that would entrust someone like Azerus with a position of power and responsibility. He was known as self-centred, greedy, and cruel towards his underlings. …
Not by chance people called him Azerus Vile behind his back.
What would you need a blood crystal for? Maybe a magician knows where to find one.
Uhm, no thanks.
I have to admit I’m a bit worried about the current state of our city.
It’s hard to tell what actually has happened there. …
According to the most prominent big bang theory, a devastating explosion laid waste most of the quarter and unleashed all kind of vile forces that made the quarter uninhabitable. …

Others claim that numerous experiments had gone wrong and that parts of the quarter had already been polluted. The great explosion was only a result of the previous disasters that had accumulated over time. …
This theory also claims that the explosion might actually have prevented the spreading of the plague to other parts of the city.
Good bye, Player.

conversation.Ethan: Welcome to the paladin guild, Player! How can I help you?
I train young paladins the art of our vocation, and an art it is without doubt. I was already teaching paladins before you were even born.
Of course it is also the knowledge of spells.
Sorry, I don’t teach spells for your vocation.
I’m Ethan.
For an old man like me everything sounds like old news.
This city has seen better days.
Tamara mentioned it sometime ago.
I hardly see any of them at all. I doubt that they care much about the things going on here. Else the city wouldn’t be the mess it is.
Their tranquil ways have preserved much of their ancient philosophy. I appreciate that.
Sorcerers have always been power-hungry maniacs, and that hasn’t changed much over the years.
The decline in knighthood seems even worse than the decline in our vocation.
What you call a paladin these days is a pale shadow of the paladins of old times. I expect my pupils to become role models and heroes, not selfish cowards.
Your vocation is your profession. There are four vocations in Tibia: paladins, knights, sorcerers, and druids.
Every paladin profits from his vocation. It has many advantages to be a paladin.
It might be a myth, but as long as it inspires people to great deeds, it should be retold.
If you are as old as I am, you don’t care about time anymore.
Magic is a weapon like any other. If it is wielded by a fool, it can be disastrous.
I’ve just had dinner, but thanks.
A paladin has to be true like his aim. A good bow and a sure hand is not enough to bring down an enemy. It also takes a pure heart and an iron will.
The stories of vampires are always filled with romance and drama. I hope I live long enough to see then end of Yalahar’s vampire story.
We will help you to improve your skills. Besides, I offer spells for paladins.
I’m 101 years old, but I don’t consider myself as too old.
I don’t even remember who was king at the time I left Thais.
Paladins are the best missile fighters in Tibia!
He seems like a fine man to me. A man that cares about his city and his people. This is something quite rare these days.
We will help you to improve your skills. Besides, I offer spells for paladins.
Paladins are great warriors and magicians. Moreover, we are excellent missile fighters. Many people in Tibia want to join us.
In a spellbook, your spells are listed. You will find the pronunciation of each spell in there. If you want to buy one, visit Xodet in the magic shop.
Of course, we aren’t as strong as knights, but no druid or sorcerer will ever defeat a paladin with a sword.
Bye, Player.

conversation.Pugwah: Uh, a brave customer! Me happy to serve you delicious food and drinks.
Me Pugwah.

Me offer bread, cheese, ham, or meat. And drinks. If you like? Ask Pugwah for trade.
Good, good! Take look at yummy food good Pugwah sells.
Me came here with little canoe. Great storm making bshhhh bshhh! Trying to drown little Pugwah! But no no! Pugwah row row row and escape! Then long long only water. …
But Pugwah have fishing rod. Many fish and drinking rain making Pugwah’s stomach sick but then Pugwah seeing city! At first Pugwah wanting eat everyone in city but Pugwah small and lonely. …

But Pugwah also smart very much! Hunting rats and selling stew Pugwah become rich! Soon buy old house and making tavern! Every one comes and eats! Stupid people selling rotten stuff so cheap, Pugwah making fortune by cooking it!
Food has to be rotten to gain flavour! No need for expensive spices!

conversation.Captain Cookie: Greetings, daring adventurer. If you need a passage, let me know.
Until I finally discover the cockaigne, I’ll work as a captain of this ship for the explorer’s society.
I can bring you to our base in Liberty Bay for 400 gold. Is that what you want?
Maybe another time.
Well, if I was a vampire I guess I’d want all the blood I could get too. So I can’t really blame them. Guess they have found their land of blood and honey already.
There is little in the world that cannot be improved with honey! I even use honey to style my hair!
I travelled here, hoping to find the cockaigne. Imagine my disappointment when I discovered I was wrong.
I wonder what kind of sweets they might prefer.
Sweets are the greatest creation of the gods ever!
Isn’t it obvious? They are explorers! If someone else but me should ever discover the cockaigne, it will be them! So I’m staying with them!
Hmm, cookies with sweetened bug milk are so delicious.
Venore’s sweets are exclusive and incredibly expensive. Once, I spent my whole wage on a night full of cookies and candies.
They have a decent assortment of sweets there.
Thais is rather dull and uninteresting when it comes to sweets.
Dwarfish sweets taste oddly. And most sorts contain alcohol.
A horrible place. You have no idea how fast chocolate is melting there!
The heat there lets chocolate melt quickly, but their candies made of sand wasp honey are something I could die for!
I just love chocolate! And honeyed chocolate I like the most!
That doesn’t sound really tasty.
Darama is a strange continent. I traveled there a long time ago in search of the cockaigne.
When I heard the story about the cockaigne as a kid, I just knew it must be the truth. A land of milk and honey must exist, and one day I’ll find it!
The dwarves and their odd cave systems …
Zao is a continent south-east of Yalahar. Many lizards live there … Creepy, I tell you!
Krailos is a faraway grassland, inhabited by savage ogres.
A really big city on the continent Kilmaresh. Its architecture is almost as impressive as Yalahar’s. The creatures there, even more so.
I can’t help it, I love sweets of any kind!
Well, this is a strange region of Tibia. All that green slime there … That’s not to my taste.
I don’t know much about him. He welcomed me to the city and was quite polite.
That’s an island east of Darashia. Full of old ruins and unholy, demonic creatures. Brrr.
I always dreamt about a ship made of sweets. But honestly I think I could not resist to taste it and would probably shipwreck it.
Yummy, the mother of all sweets!
Go away. Everything there tastes salty or oily. They use all their honey to produce mead. What a waste!
I sometimes wonder why the gods did not make the ocean taste like lemonade. I guess if they did, it would have been drunken dry already.
Get off my raft!
Good bye.

conversation.Morpel: As a smith I know better than to underestimate the power of fire, jawoll. It seems the alchemists never learnt this lesson.

I can’t say I have the guts to pay this quarter a visit.

conversation.Bruce: Good day, sir. If you have no official business or want to pass the gate, please move on.
There has been a huge explosion due to some unknown experiments. Ever since then, the quarter is contaminated.
This used to be a great recreation area with a zoo and a lively arena.
They are our supervisors.
This is the quarter to the east. Don’t expect any worshippers of our Tibian gods though.
Those old and malfunctioning machines could pose a threat to civilians.
It’s a snowy island to the west.
New inhabitants are arriving daily, and most will be stuck in the foreigners’ quarter forever.
Which island are you talking about? Mistrock, Fenrock or Vengoth?
Master Sergeant of the Yalaharian Guard Force, sir.
I have huge respect for those highly educated magicians living there and dealing with the other magical creatures each day.
What is that mission you are talking about?
No one knows what this island is really called, but the people stick with ‘mistrock’ due to it being covered in mist.
My name is Bruce.
Should I let you pass the gate? Are you headed for the alchemist or the cemetery quarter?
Our guards protect the gates between all eight quarters.
I have nothing to say about that topic.
The quarter collapsed into the ocean.
I think it’s an outrage that this quarter is controlled by criminals.
One day the vampires on Vengoth will become a big threat. We should expect the worst from that place.
I will protect this city with my life.
Goodbye citizen!

conversation.Soilance: Hi, Player. I assume you are here for a good old trade.

They are .. uhm just there to get rid of the garbage. Don’t pay them any attention.
I .. import that meat from several sources which I cannot reveal for the safety of my small profit.

I haven’t even seen one in my life.
He should care more about the city instead of harassing innocent traders like me.
I offer ham or meat. If you’d like to see my offers, ask me for a trade.

I have an agreement with Mr. West which provides that I supply his people with meat.
They used to fish there a lot, but fish seems to become quite rare lately. Luckily, I provide the city with delicious meat!
I heard nothing good about this quarter.
Those barbaric monsters have no taste at all.
I have an agreement with Mr. West which provides that I supply his people with meat.

I supply this part of the city with meat.

conversation.Barry: Hello. Unless you have official business here or want to pass the gate, please move on.
I’d be careful if I went there. Some people have never come back, and those who did are ill in one or the other way.
A lot of trouble has been coming from that quarter lately. It seems that the former fighters and gladiators have changed in most unexpected ways.
They were appointed by the Yalahari to execute supervising and controlling tasks.
You will not be able to attend any religious ceremonies in that quarter, that’s a fact. Better stay away.
The old factory is just south of here. The machines and worker golems are not really functioning anymore, but you still hear their operating sounds.
Yes, you’re right. People are calling that snowy island Fenrock.
I’m glad I don’t have to do shifts there. It’s interesting, but there are constantly fights going on.
Neither Captain Karith nor Captain Cookie are sailing to the outer islands. I haven’t found anyone yet to bring me there.

A quarter full of talented magicians, illustrious figures and dangerous magical creatures. The latter cause most of the problems in this quarter.
Excuse me? I’m not sure which mission you are talking about, just tell me what you want from me.
Mistrock? Yes, maybe that’s the name. I’m not sure.
I’m called Barry.
Do you want to pass the gate? Are you going to the magician or the sunken quarter?
We have eight quarters plus the centre, and each of them is like an own microcosm.
This is of no importance to me right now.
You know, I was guarding this gate here at the time the southern quarter collapsed. It’s something I’ll never be able to erase from my mind.
Mr. West is not as bad as some people make him look like. He’s a bit like ‘steal from the rich to give it to the poor’, in my opinion.
I heard about Vengoth, but not much.
I actually like the city. There’s so much going on in all those small streets and corners, it’s really entertaining.
Goodbye citizen!

conversation.Armenius: Ah, an adventurer. Be greeted and have a seat. How may I serve you?
Don’t you know that when you know a person’s name, you hold some power over that person?
Uh huh. Scary, you can read the name on my bar.
We offer bread, cheese, ham, and meat, as well as eggs and tomatoes. Ask for a trade if you want to have a look.
That’s not a serious question, is it? I’m running a bar. Duh. Are you interested in my offers?
Didn’t your mama teach you? Ask for a trade if you want to see what my bar has to offer.
Sure.
If you want blood, go kill a pig.
Why would you ask that? I give you a hint – don’t meddle in affairs you haven’t the slightest idea about.
Oh, don’t talk about him. Little Mr. Know-it-all, he is.
Isn’t that the fruit guy? Yes, I’ve seen him.
Don’t see him often. He basically lives on the opposite side of the city.
He prefers to visit a nobler tavern than mine. Pff.
Isn’t that the fruit guy? Yes, I’ve seen him.
A former pirate I think.
Fine place for me right now. Lots of… supplies.
Go away, little fly.
It’d be better for you to leave now.
This quarter might look a little run-down, but I prefer that to the shallow golden glory of the inner city.
I got beer, wine and some imported rum.
Why would I have a mission for you? Have a drink and pay for it, that’s your first mission in my bar.
You know, actually I don’t feel like chatting with you much. Sorry, kid.
Unimportant gofers.
He’s not a bad person, even from my point of view. Lots of criminals find shelter in this quarter, which means more people who come and visit my bar.
Good bye.

conversation.Jimmy: Hello my friend. What’s up?
Guess what? I’m a thief!
People call me Jimmy Swiftfinger.
What’s that? Never heard of it.
This city is a huge jail with its keepers in the middle. I’ve never seen its former brilliance so I rather see it in a negative light.
I don’t like them and I can’t see how they should ever have managed to build a city like this. I mean, they were never able to organise that many people.
Some dwarfs live in Yalahar but they are not very talkative. I have no clue where they came from.
Never heard of that.
This island is weird. It’s definitely no ordinary mist that covers the island most of the days. To me it looks more like….steam from a chimney.
I’ve never been there because there is no reason to go. It is cold and the island is small and meagre.
We had a deal and I kept my word, so what do you want? You’d better leave now.
I don’t kill people.
I was a little boy when the quarter blew up. It was a huge explosion and the stench was evil. No one made it out there alive. Every living being mutated into some monster.
What are they producing there anyway? Tell me if you find out.
I sneaked in once. You have to know that it is not allowed for ‘normal’ citizens like me to enter. They carry out dark experiments there, that’s for sure.
No one knows what really happened there. The whole quarter is overrun with undead and demonic creatures. It’s the work of the mages if you ask me.
A smart person like you has surely seen that most of the city has grown larger than the island it was built on. The Yalahari built metal construction to enlarge the city. …
Well, in the case of the sunken quarter, it didn’t work out. The whole quarter broke away and sunk into the sea.
The foreigner quarter is almost as shabby as the trade quarter. Be careful there or you might get in trouble.

I like the zoo quarter. I often go there and watch the animals. One advice, though: Stay away from the arena! The gladiators there are always up for a fight and there are rumours about some very strong undead gladiators deep down under the arena.

conversation.Tamoril: Another pesky mortal who believes his gold outweighs his nutrition value.
I share some of my eternal knowledge of spells with you humans … for a price of course. You should be grateful.
My real name is not pronounceable for a human.
You puny mortals are an annoyance. However, the little magic your simple minds are able to comprehend earns me enough money not to kill you.
I share some of my eternal knowledge of spells with you humans … for a price of course. You should be grateful.
The city is dying. It is mortal just like you and for this reason, it is insignificant. I will still be around when this city is long forgotten.
Dragons are the most powerful creatures of the world. Every year, we gain more and more power. …
Hardly anyone of us dies of old age. Instead we find death by diseases brought to our race by you mortal pests, and countless of my younger brethren and sisters have been slaughtered by humans. …
Expect little from me mortal. And even for that little, you will have to pay dearly.
What you call magic is only a pale shadow of real magic. The more you try, the more magic will retreat from you. …
To us dragons magic comes natural. It is a part of us, and not a tool we have to learn to control like you do.
I can teach you rune spells and instant spells. What kind of spell do you wish to learn? You can also tell me for which level you would like to learn a spell, if you prefer that.
They are strange beings at best. If I had any interest in mortals, I might be curious. Regardless of what they claim, they smell of mortality.
I’m not surprised about the things that happened there. Humans are unable to handle the higher forces.
Another bunch of humans who dabbles in the arcane arts to become godlike beings.
I’m not surprised about the things that happened there. Humans are unable to handle the higher forces.
You humans are unable to live on your own. You rely on your little tools and protection. Your sheer inferiority makes me sick.
That was only the beginning. I will be there when everything comes to an end.
A museum of races who will sooner or later be wiped out.
Sometimes I fly there for some exercise.
I’m not interested in your human quarrels.
Gods are of no use for us dragons. One day, a dragon will become old and powerful enough to destroy all gods. Fear that day mortal, from then on the age of the dragons will have begun.
Do you want to learn the spell ‘Animate Dead Rune’ for 1200 gold?
Then not.
Here you are. Look in your spellbook for the pronunciation of this spell.
If I had one, I’d surely add it to my treasure and not give it to you.
I usually prefer to plunder instead of a fair trade. However, I have enough gold and could use some more shiny valuables.
Come back if you dare, Player.

conversation.Lorietta: Hi there, Player! What do you need?
My name is Lorietta. But why do you ask? I knew your name without asking. Guess how!
I guess I’m the local priest! They said only a priest of Kurik would be crazy enough to try spreading the faith in this town. And I tell you what: They have been soooo right!
Oh, we heal people and … and … do other nice stuff. You know?!
You do not need any healing right now.

Kurik is the patron saint of jesters, fools, and inventors. This might sound strange, but do you know any inventor that isn’t also a fool to some extent, and don’t you think jesters are quite inventive?
In its golden age, this city must have been a joy for Kurik’s eye. Even today you can still see some of its former glory here and there.
They must have been great inventors in the past. Nowadays not much of that is left. I guess they were foolish enough to let things slide.
As long as I don’t invite them into my temple I’ll be fine.
He’s a bit too boring for my taste.
Tibia is quite big, isn’t it?
Keep your adventurer’s stone well.
Ehehehe! A blood crystal? You must be a fool looking for one. I like fools. Why don’t you check the cultist hideout in the magician quarter?
The gods created all.
Life can be a cruel joke sometimes.
People come, people go.

Now that’s some story. I’ve told it numerous times to tourists – <coughs>, I mean, adventurers – but it still makes me shiver each time. …
As you might have already noticed, Yalahar is huge. HUGE. The city has grown so much over the past centuries that eventually there was no space left for new buildings. …

However, due to the constant flow of immigrants, the citizens just kept on building and building – either placing buildings on top of each other or trying to enhance the space with platforms on the water. …
Then, a few decades ago, there was a day which I still remember vividly, because I was right in the middle of the whole disaster happening. …
I just came back from the centre and was on the way to my house located in the east quarter – today situated several feet below us under the ocean surface. …
Suddenly the earth was shaking and I heard a loud rumbling. I was still wondering what on earth was going on, or if we were under attack, when I saw the houses closest to the ocean collapse. …
Just like that! The ground under them broke away and fell into the ocean, and then – imagine that – like a wave of destruction, terror rushed through the whole quarter. …

I heard people screaming and more houses tumbling down, and immediately I rushed back to the centre, behind the solid city walls – even though they didn’t seem so solid at that time, but it was the safest place I could get to. …
From there I had to helplessly watch how the whole quarter fell apart. Large chunks of stone and earth collapsed into the ocean, and with them all of my belongings. …
When the wave of destruction reached the wall separating the quarter from the other parts of the city, that wall also sunk into the ocean and must have worked as a barrier down there. …
You can still see the top of the old wall sticking out of the water. After that last collapse, the destruction stopped all of a sudden. …
Only a few people, among them myself as you can see, were able to survive the great downfall. The rest was buried under their houses, or drowned in the ocean. Such cruel fate… …

conversation.Iriana: Hello there. Wanna buy some fishing equipment? Just ask me for a trade.

The city once had 8 quarters excluding the centre. Right now you are in the former trade quarter, east of it you find the factory quarter. Further to the north-east you find the quarter known as the sunken quarter …

followed by the magician quarter. Then you have the most northern quarter, known as the cemetery quarter, and west of that you find the former alchemist quarter. The most western quarter is the former zoo and arena quarter …

conversation.Balduin The Baker: Hi there Bennie. I guess you are here to assist me in my job!

I'm a member of the Magic Bakery Alliance. We are an order that is dedicated to further the knowledge of bakery for the benefit of mankind. Our goals are as numerous as the recipes we come up with each season.
Currently we are trying to reclaim another part of Kullu's wisdom. Year after year, we try our best to break the defences of Cake Keep Isle.

He was a great mage but an even greater cook. His recipes and spells are priceless. Sadly, even if we succeed in breaking the defences of Cake Keep Isle, we will only manage to decipher a tiny fraction of his knowledge. ...
And still, we don't know what happened to Kullu. He retreated from our world to fully concentrate on his research on cooking recipes and spells. ...
He was some sweet tooth for all that we know. And for sure a genius when it comes to baking and magic. ...
His kitchen magic was that amazing, you could not tell where baking ended and magic started.
To be undisturbed, he placed his keep on an isle that existed on a planar instability which allowed him to phase the isle out of existence for most of the time. ...
Additionally he surrounded the isle with a sorcery of his invention that defied most attempts to reach it. ...
It took us quite a while to figure out that he'd never be able to weave a protection spell against something he loved so dearly like cakes and bakery wares. ...
So we came up with the idea of the bridge.

After a few failed attempts with gingerbread boats and the like, we figured out how to reach Cake Keep Isle. We used the very ingredients we could derive from his cake golem attacks to build a stable cake bridge to his isle.
Ah well, that's an .. uhm .. funny story. ...
You see, after the first expedition reached the isle, they took so long trying to find a way to Kullu's secrets that the isle began to vanish into the void while they were still there. ...
The entire time, they were harassed by Kullu's cake golem guardians of the keep. In the last minute, they cast emergency teleports to their home cities. ...
The good thing is it was not too late and all escaped. Well, the bad thing is their spells somehow reacted with the void-rift of that place, building astral tunnels from the void to said cities. ...

Now, whenever the isle manifests, the tunnels manifest as well. The ugly part is that through this one-way tunnels the cake golem army that was apparently sucked into the void has access to the cities and can raid them. ...
But they are not only an annoyance but also our greatest chance. Nasty but tasty little buggers. They can be troublesome but we need them for our bridge construction.
The golems that raid the cities supply us with two major materials that we need to build our bridge to Cake Keep Isle. ...
One component is the sugary mass that can be gained if you slay one of them. We use it as a kind of mortar. ...

The second part is a bit trickier to get. It is the raw cake material. It is kind of challenging to gain it. We built extraction machines that can drain the base material from the still animated corpses. ...
We placed one in each of the raided cities. You will have to lure the golems into the machines, to extract the material from them. ...
We need it to have a stable base material that is resilient against wind, weather and salt water.
We accumulated 116 of 200 sugary mass. We can't fail this year! We will not allow it!
I'm somewhat worried. Getting the base material is always the tricky part. People are usually a bit too eager to kill. We accumulated 140 of 200 base material until now.
We are a mystic order of bakers who pursue goals for the benefit of all mankind. Don't even listen to the lies and propaganda spread by those who envy us.
Though most of our noble order abandoned the more theoretical studies at the academies, it is an evil lie that we are failed students who know more about drinking and eating than about magic. ...
Once we have revealed all of Kullu's secrets, we will be envied by all. And of course we all will become famous and incredibly rich.
We are a mystic baker order. Don't listen to those who envy us and spread ugly lies and propaganda. We are dedicated to uncover the greatest secrets about cooking and baking. ...
Baking is the only trade worth to be considered. Without bakers everyone would starve. We are what ties a society together, preferably with a thick, sticky and sweet mass made of fruits. ...
We are the momentum of culture. Baking is what divides civilization from barbarism.
Good bye.

conversation.Hjaern: Be greeted, Player. The spiritual world looks upon you and your deeds.
The spirits call me by the name of Hjaern and that is how I shall be known.
I would not consider this as a job. But one of my responsibilities is the training of young shamans. Even druids can learn a few new tricks from me.
We try to figure out the will of the spirits and ways to appease them.
The news I receive are from the spiritual world. They would be of little importance for you.
We had no contact with the people that passed Svargrond. Their arrival has caused some disturbance in  the spirits' world though. ...
Ancient spirits are restless. It seems that some things that should have been left alone, have awoken from their slumber. I can't tell more yet.
Your foreign gods are concepts we don't really understand.
There should be no such thing like a human that is ruling over the lives of other humans.
The chakoyas are like a force of nature. It would be wrong to try to exterminate them. On the other hand, we can't allow their carnivorous nature to threaten our lives.
The yetis are real. They are elusive but dangerous. Some say they are rather residents of the spirits' world than ours. The spirits are silent about them which is an even greater enigma.
He is of no importance here.
The city was a necessity. Just like the spirit needs a haven of safety and retreat, so does the body need it.
That's something I only heard about in curious questions of people like you.
Months ago, many strange looking people passed Svargrond. The inhabitants tell stories about a cult they belong to. ...
It is rumoured that they are trying to awake unholy spirits in the mountains. Maybe other people know more about that cult.
Father north wind is the supreme ruler of the North. His ways are almost unpredictable to us humans since his thoughts span ages. ...

We can only do our best to interpret his will correctly and act accordingly. One has to move with the wind after all, else it will destroy you. This is the way things are here in the North and the way of our people.
