Good monsters to start with are rats. They live in the sewers under the village of Rookgaard.
There are many sewer entrances throughout Rookgaard. One is right outside this shop and to the left. For more details about monsters and dungeons, best talk to one of the guards.
The king encouraged salesmen to travel here, but only I dared to take the risk, and a risk it was!
The bridge guard Dallheim is north of here, just follow the street, you can't miss it.
It's really heart-warming to see how the Tibia economy is prospering.
Oh, you're welcome, very welcome.

conversation.Cipfried: Hello, Player! I’ll heal you if you are injured or poisoned. Feel free to ask me for help or general hints.
My name is Cipfried.
Me? Oh, I’m just a humble monk. Ask me if you need help or healing.
I have sacrificed my life to serve the good gods of Tibia and to help newcomers in this world.
That’s where we are – the world of Tibia, in a village called Rookgaard, to be precise, with many monsters, quests and citizens around.
The gods have chosen this isle as the point of arrival for newborn souls. The citizens will help you if you ask them.
They created Tibia and all life on it. Visit our academy and learn about them.
Only a few people live in our village, most of them are merchants. You can either ask them for a trade or about various other topics, like the names of other citizens, their job or Tibia in general.
Obi’s shop is to the north-east of this humble temple. He sells weapons, and his granddaughter Dixi sells armor and shields upstairs.
Seymour is a loyal follower of the king and a teacher in the academy.
Willie is a farmer, just like his cousin Billy. His farm is located left of the temple. You can buy and sell food there.
The academy is just north of here. You can learn helpful things there from Seymour, if you wish to!
He’s a farmer, just like his cousin Willie. He doesn’t talk to everybody, though.
Monsters are a constant threat to this village. You would tremendously help us by fighting them, starting with rats in the sewers, then turning to spiders or wolves.
A single rat doesn’t pose a grave danger to you, but be careful not to get cornered by many of them. They could still kill you.
The sewers are right below this village. North of this temple, you find a sewer grate which leads down, but there are also many small huts in the village which are connected to the sewers.
If you get killed, you will revive in this temple. However, you will lose experience and also equipment, which can be quite painful. Take good care of yourself!
To defend yourself against enemies, you will need a weapon. You can purchase weapons at Obi’s shop.
To defend yourself against enemies, you will need armor and shields. You can purchase both at Dixi’s shop.
To defend yourself against enemies, you will need armor and shields. You can purchase both at Dixi’s shop.
That’s Obi’s granddaughter. Her counter is just upstairs from Obi’s shop. She helps him by selling armor and shields.
You can buy and sell goods from merchants. To do so, simply talk to them and ask them for a trade. They will gladly show you their offers and also the things they buy from you.
You can buy equipment from the merchants in this village once you earned some gold. Some monsters also carry equipment pieces with them.
You aren’t looking really bad, Player. I can only help in cases of real emergencies. Raise your health simply by eating food.
Food is very important for your health. If you are hurt in a fight with a monster, select ‘Use’ on food such as cheese, ham or meat to eat it. This will slowly refill your health.
How can I help you? I can tell you about specific citizens if you tell me their name. I can also give you general hints about Tibia.
Oh, I can handle my tasks myself, thank you. If you are looking for something to do, you should listen to the local citizens and ask them for quests. You could also help us fight monsters.
You can earn a fair amount of gold by fighting monsters and picking up the things they carry. Many citizens are buying some of that loot, simply ask around.
Now it is 9:58 pm, my child.
He came together with Vascalir. He seems like a powerful mage and investigates the disturbances in the magical atmosphere.
He has recently arrived from a far-away country to help us fight against the orcs.
Amber is such a lovely girl, and also a very experienced explorer and adventurer. It’s always interesting to chat with her.
I can see a bright future for you… you will soon embark on a very big adventure and explore the world of Tibia – maybe even influence history!
In Al Dee’s shop you’ll find important general equipment such as ropes, shovels and torches.
Never go adventuring without a rope! If you don’t have one when you fall through a hole in the ground, you won’t be able to leave without a rope.
Shovels are very useful. There may be a hidden entrance under a loose pile of stone and without a shovel, how would you know?
May the gods bless our loyal guardsmen! Day and night they stand watch on our bridges, ensuring that it is not passed by dangerous monsters!
Yes? How can I help you?
Knights are close combat fighters. They usually wield melee weapons such as swords, axes or clubs.
Paladins are well-trained distance fighters and can cast holy magic. You will usually see them wearing bows or crossbows.
Druids are nature magicians. Their speciality is casting ice and earth magic, as well as providing healing for others.
Sorcerers are elemental magicians. They have mastered fire, energy and death magic.
You can find the oracle on the top floor of the academy, just above Seymour. Go there when you are level 8 to find your destiny.
There are four vocations in Tibia: knight, sorcerer, paladin or druid. Each vocation has its unique special abilities.
Your near destiny will be to choose a vocation once you are level 8. Whether you will become a knight, sorcerer, paladin or druid is a big decision!
Potions will come in handy once you are in a fight deep in a dungeon. If you aren’t in immediate danger, you can simply eat food to regain health, though.
If you face spiders, beware of the poisonous ones. If you are poisoned, you will constantly lose health. Come to me and I’ll heal you from poison.
Poison is very dangerous! Don’t ever drink green liquids, they are poisonous and will make you lose health!
Wolves can only be found outside of the village. If you want to know where their dens are, best talk to Dallheim or Zerbrus at the bridges.
Of course.
Hyacinth is a close friend of mine. He left the village many years ago to live in solitude. I think all this bustle here simply was too much for him.
Lee’Delle’s shop is on the premium side of the village. You should visit her!
As a premium adventurer, you are an official tax payer and thus privileged in many ways. For example, you can travel by ship and get better deals from merchants.
Ships are a comfortable way of travelling to distant cities. At any harbour, you can board the ship and ask its captain where he sails to. …
Travelling by ship will cost you some gold, though, so be sure to have money with you.
You must have passed the house of Lily on your way here. She sells potions. If you pick blueberries or find cookies, she’ll buy them from you.
I’m sorry, but I’m not interested in worldly goods. If you want to buy or sell something, you should ask a local merchant for a trade.
That’s a sad story. He used to help me guard this temple, but for some reason he went out of his mind.
She recently opened a little bar north of this village.
He is the bank clerk, making sure your money remains safe.
You can deposit your money at the bank. That way you won’t lose it if you get killed. The bank is just under the academy and to the right.
Seymour is a loyal follower of the king and a teacher in the academy.
I don’t have any goods for trade, but if you ask one of the merchants, he or she will gladly show you what you can buy or sell.
Well, King Tibianus of course. The island of Rookgaard belongs to his kingdom.
Tom is the main provider for leather armor in this village. You can sell fresh corpses or even minotaur leather to him.
May the gods bless our loyal guardsmen! Day and night they stand watch on our bridges, ensuring that it is not passed by dangerous monsters!
Hey Player! We have rules here! You’ll have a much easier life if you respect them.
A general rule is to be polite and kind towards fellow Tibians. This includes not to insult them or to steal their monsters. If you are friendly, you will quickly make friends.
I absolutely appreciate what he’s doing. He has helped me a lot since he took up the job of welcoming newcomers to this island.
That old lady hasn’t had an easy life. Her son Tom completely abandoned her, but I have no idea why.
If you don’t know the meaning of an icon on the right side, move the mouse cursor on it and wait a moment.

Send private messages to other players by right-clicking on the player or the player’s name and select ‘Message to ….’. You can also open a ‘private message channel’ and type in the name of the player.
Use the shortcuts ‘SHIFT’ to look, ‘CTRL’ for use and ‘ALT’ for attack when clicking on an object or player.
If you already know where you want to go, click on the automap and your character will walk there automatically if the location is reachable and not too far away.
To open or close skills, battle or VIP list, click on the corresponding button to the right.
‘Capacity’ restricts the amount of things you can carry with you. It raises with each level.
Always have a look on your health bar. If you see that you do not regenerate health points anymore, eat something.
Always eat as much food as possible. This way, you’ll regenerate health points for a longer period of time.
After you have killed a monster, you have 10 seconds in which the corpse is not moveable and no one else but you can loot it.
Be careful when you approach three or more monsters because you only can block the attacks of two. In such a situation even a few rats can do severe damage or even kill you.

There are many ways to gather food. Many creatures drop food but you can also pick blueberries or bake your own bread. If you have a fishing rod and worms in your inventory, you can also try to catch a fish.
Baking bread is rather complex. First of all you need a scythe to harvest wheat. Then you use the wheat with a millstone to get flour. …
This can be be used on water to get dough, which can be used on an oven to bake bread. Use milk instead of water to get cake dough.
Dying hurts! Better run away than risk your life. You are going to lose experience and skill points when you die.
When you switch to ‘Offensive Fighting’, you deal out more damage but you also get hurt more easily.
When you are on low health and need to run away from a monster, switch to ‘Defensive Fighting’ and the monster will hit you less severely.
Many creatures try to run away from you. Select ‘Chase Opponent’ to follow them.

The deeper you enter a dungeon, the more dangerous it will be. Approach every dungeon with utmost care or an unexpected creature might kill you. This will result in losing experience and skill points.
Due to the perspective, some objects in Tibia are not located at the spot they seem to appear (ladders, windows, lamps). Try clicking on the floor tile the object would lie on.
If you want to trade an item with another player, right-click on the item and select ‘Trade with …’, then click on the player with whom you want to trade.
Stairs, ladders and dungeon entrances are marked as yellow dots on the automap.
You can get food by killing animals or monsters. You can also pick blueberries or bake your own bread. If you are too lazy or own too much money, you can also buy food.
Quest containers can be recognised easily. They don’t open up regularly but display a message ‘You have found ….’. They can only be opened once.
Better run away than risk to die. You’ll lose experience and skill points each time you die.
You can form a party by right-clicking on a player and selecting ‘Invite to Party’. The party leader can also enable ‘Shared Experience’ by right-clicking on him- or herself.
You can assign spells, the use of items, or random text to ‘hotkeys’. You find them under ‘Options’.
You can also follow other players. Just right-click on the player and select ‘Follow’.
You can found a party with your friends by right-clicking on a player and selecting ‘Invite to Party’. If you are invited to a party, right-click on yourself and select ‘Join Party’.

Only found parties with people you trust. You can attack people in your party without getting a skull. This is helpful for training your skills, but can be abused to kill people without having to fear negative consequences.
The leader of a party has the option to distribute gathered experience among all players in the party. If you are the leader, right-click on yourself and select ‘Enable Shared Experience’.
There is nothing more I can tell you. If you are still in need of some hints, I can repeat them for you.
Farewell, Player!

conversation.Hyacinth: Greetings, traveller Leonardo Dikarpio. As you have found the way to my hut, how can I help you?
What help do you seek? I sell health potions, ask me for a trade if you need one.
Here. Don’t forget, if you buy potions, there’s a deposit of 5 gold on the empty flask.
I’ll pay you 5 gold for every empty vial and potion flask. Just ask me for a trade.
I’m a druid and healer, a follower of Crunor.
I’m Hyacinth.
There are only two other druids on Rookgaard, Lily and Cipfried.
May Crunor bless you and protect you on your journeys!
She’s a druid. Since she started selling health potions, people visit me only rarely. Which is a good thing, but of course I’ll help if I’m needed.
His healing powers equal mine.
Yes, I sell small health potions. Ask me for a trade if you need one.
Now she has completely gotten out of her mind.
Just ask me for a trade to check out my offers. I have only small health potions for sale, though.
Teaching you about the gods would require too much time. But you can always read the books in the library.
The library is in the academy, north of the temple.
A place to learn about Tibia.
It is shaped by the will of the gods, so we don’t have to question it.
I used to be there with my old friend Cipfried to heal adventurers. After all these years, I prefer solitude now.
I rarely visit the town. It’s much better here.
I don’t care about kings, queens, and the like.
One of these greedy merchants.
He’s a farmer and behaves a little better than his cousin.
An unpleasant person.
A man of the sword.
That’s my name.
I think she’s under bad influence.
She’s actually quite nice.
He was a promising young druid when something happened to his mind. It’s a sad story.
I think that guy is new. He’s a bank clerk.
Storage for worldly wealth.
A greedy and annoying person just like most people are.
He does a good job out there.
He has some inner devils that torture him.
The oracle will lead you to your destiny once you are level 8.
Who knows what it will be? Only time will show.
Time doesn’t matter to me.
Tom is the local tanner. That means he always needs fresh corpses or leather.
A man of the sword.
I know her since she was little.
There’s a huge world waiting for you.

I don’t care much about weapons.
Are you hungry? I’m sorry, I have no food here.

Thank the gods, I’m fine.
You’re welcome, Leonardo Dikarpio.
I’m one of the few magic users on this isle. I can sense a follower of the dark path of magic hiding somewhere in the depths of the dungeons.
I saw her stranding with her raft.
I can’t teach you magic. On the mainland you will learn spells early enough.
Most of the so-called monsters of this isle are only creatures of the gods. There are some beasts that are truly monstrous on the mainland.

conversation.Dixi: Hello, Mam. How may I help you, Player.
If you need something, please let me know.
I'm helping my grandfather Obi with this shop. Do you want to buy or sell anything?
We're selling many things. Please have a look at the blackboards downstairs to see a list of our inventory.
We sell spears, rapiers, sabres, daggers, hand axes, axes, and short swords. Just tell me what you want to buy.
We sell jackets, coats, doublets, leather armor, and leather legs. Just tell me what you want to buy.
We sell leather helmets, studded helmets, and chain helmets. Just tell me what you want to buy.
We sell torches, bags, scrolls, shovels, picks, backpacks, sickles, scythes, ropes, fishing rods and sixpacks of worms. Just tell me what you want to buy.

conversation.Dallheim: <nods> At your service, Player, protecting the village from monsters.
All that theory won’t help you without some real battle practice.
He has been on this island as long as me.
I don’t trust her.
Before you fight monsters, deposit your money there. If you die, you won’t lose it if it’s save in the bank.
The heavenly warrior! Hail to him!
A bear can easily kill you if you don’t pay attention.
He is a fine cook and farmer. He buys and sells food.
They are a little tougher than they look like, but they’re still good beginner monsters.
He guards the temple and can heal you if you are badly injured or poisoned, just like me.
I’ll protect all citizens alike. That is my job and duty.
Nasty but easy to squish.
At your service.
They don’t pose a threat. However, if you need food, they are good meat providers.
She’s Obi’s granddaughter and deals with armors and shields. Her shop is south west of town, close to the temple.
I can mark you some dungeons on your map if you ask me about monsters suited for your level.
I’m a follower of Banor.
You aren’t looking really bad. Eat some food to regain strength.
I have to stay here, sorry. But I can heal you if you are wounded. I have also valuable information about monsters.
Fine.
Strange fellow, hides somewhere in the mountains of the isle.
I’m an expert concerning the wildlife and monsters on this island.
I’m the guard of this bridge. I defend Rookgaard against the beasts of the wilderness and the dungeons, and even of the stinking sewers.
HAIL TO THE KING!
Her shop is on the premium side of town. Best offers around.
Sometimes I wish I had an easy job like her, selling potions all day.
Zerbrus tells me such strange stories about him. Well, he sees him all day from the west bridge.
I’m not interested in such party tricks.
Minotaurs are very strong. You will need a group of people or at least level 6 and good equipment to be able to kill them.
It looks like you have mastered the drill.
Dallheim, at your service.
I don’t approve of her opening a bar. Those drunken adventurers stumbling over the bridge at nighttime are not especially helpful in improving the situation.
He sells weapons. His shop is south west of town, close to the temple.
You can find the oracle on the top floor of the academy, just above Seymour. Go there when you are level 8.
Orcs are a constant menace. There are even stronger species of orcs on the main continent.
The local bank clerk.
Premium warriors pay. They gain many advantages this way.
They don’t pose a threat. However, if you need food, they are good meat providers.
Did you know that rats are among the most dangerous animals in whole Tibia? Each day, they kill many people who are overestimating their powers. Don’t be one of them!
It’s my duty to protect this village and its citizens.
Rotworms should not be taken lightly. They hit hard. Once you are on mainland with a vocation and proper equipment, you will learn to love them.
He dedicated his life to welcoming newcomers to this island.
Just recently they’ve come to this island for nesting. They aren’t dangerous.
The sewers are crowded with rats. They make fine targets for young heroes.
Leave me alone with this wimp.
The skeletons on this island are usually fairly hidden. They are often found near graves and always underground. Beware of their evil life drain.
Snakes can poison you, too, but their poison is usually not as dangerous as that of poison spiders. Just be careful and kill them fast.
Spearmen are the toughest orcs on this island. Beware their distance attack!
There are two types of spiders on this island: normal spiders and poison spiders. As their name says, the latter ones can poison you which will cause a constant loss of your health. Beware of them!
A place of protection. Nothing can harm you there.
It’s my job.
A nice place for a hero, but nothing for whelps.
My duty is eternal. Time is of no importance.
He’s the local tanner. You could try selling fresh corpses or leather to him.

conversation.Telas: Hello! Sorry I’m a bit busy.
I guess, my job is my passion.
As you know I’m a scientist, specialising in the field of creating golems. That is my mission so to say.

After all this effort we have made it, my friend! I can’t figure out why the golem is behaving so strangely. I can only assume the experimental head was not completely indoctrinated with all the usual golem routines …
But that might even prove helpful. I will try to teach the golem what he needs to know, but it will take some time. Feel free to visit whenever you like if you want to hear about my progress. …
By the way, I could also need certain rare metals and crystals for my experiments. Just in case you have any of those I need, ask me for a trade to exchange them for good money!
Seen any of those metals, stones or crystals? I’ll happily buy them! I also buy crystal pedestals.
Well you don’t have any, but in case you find some, let me know!
The city itself deeply affects me for many different reasons. …
For one, the wonders and the technology to be found in the city fill me with awe. …
And then I am filled with sadness for the decline of their technology and the loss of their knowledge that is palpable everywhere in the city.
The Yalahari are a race of contrasts. Though admittedly it’s probably better to regard the Yalahari of the past and the Yalahari of today as two completely different races. …
In the past the Yalahari were reclusive but brilliant. You can still see all the marvels of their city and all the knowledge in different fields of science that they must have possessed. …
Then, at some point in their history something must have happened, causing a shift in their society. …
Science stopped progressing and was gradually forgotten. No new wonders were built and the old ones slowly fell into decay. …
It seems that over the course of generations, the Yalahari increasingly lost touch with their own inventions. …
We can only speculate what might have happened. …
I, for my part, think that scientific knowledge was probably exclusive to a small group of Yalaharian elite. …
I have seen with my own eyes that one quarter of their city was devastated by an explosion and another sunk into the sea because of an earthquake. …
My theory is that the scientific elite perished along with one of these quarters, thus leading to the downfall of the Yalaharian civilisation. …
The Yalahari of today are quite reclusive and don’t like visitors in their inner sanctum – as I learnt the hard way. …
I used a lot of influence and wealth to gain admittance to their inner city. Unfortunately, they quickly cast me out because they found me too curious.
Many people actually mean magic when they say ‘science’. But there are so many other fields to be explored. …
The more mundane sciences hold many secrets of their own and can be profoundly rewarding for a researcher.
Earth is a rather basic element for golem construction. Earth golems can be created without much effort and are quite common.
My name is Telas.
The term golem is a bit too broad to describe the actual diversity of these beings. …
Roughly speaking, most golems are based on an element which is concentrated until it gains a semblance of sentience. …
The element that is concentrated can be changed to get a different kind of golem. …
The ‘element’ does not necessarily have to be earth, fire, water or air but, purely theoretically, concentrations of other matter are possible. …
It is still under debate whether most of the other concentrations of matter could be traced back to one of the core elements. …
Since this science is still in its infancy there is a lot to be specified and researched.
So far, science has recognized four elements: water, fire, air and earth. It is speculated that there are more elements in existence, such as lightning, magic, life and unlife.
Water can sometimes be concentrated by using its ice form as a base. …
Although concentrating water is not as problematic as with most of the other elements, it is difficult to keep the concentrated water stable for an extended period of time.
The brute force of fire makes it dangerous to contain and difficult to concentrate without risk of an explosion.
Air is elusive and the techniques to concentrate it are exceptionatly complicated.
Lightning is still an unexplained phenomenon. Some assume it is an element in its own right, others claim it is the product of opposing elements. …
Others suggest it belongs to the element of magic and finally there are those who claim that lightning is a Godly element.
Magic is a fascinating field, both in terms of theory and practice. Unfortunately, with all the manpower and resources that have been put into that area, other areas have been somewhat neglected …

When confronted with a problem people have grown used to turning to magic for a solution. We’ll never know how many inventions might have been discovered if there weren’t already a spell for everything.
Life, as an element, is rather speculative. …
Some argue that we are a form of concentrated life and therefore would qualify as life golems. …
This is an intriguing concept and when I am done with my current research I will probably give that a closer look.
Spells have a tendency to make things easy. Too easy for my taste. People stop thinking for themselves if they have a spell for each and every occasion at hand. …
All the bookish knowledge of a studied master does not make up for the practical experience of an ordinary man who has to solve his problems by original thinking.
I admit I have little use for the Gods in my own life. I like to think that I make my own decisions. …
I really can’t understand devout believers who follow the doctrines of a God, or rather, his priests and subordinate their life to the agenda of some heavenly power. …
If the stories of the God Wars are true, then I am not sure I feel comfortable with the idea of being some kind of a weapon and not an individual.
Well, we all know that the Gods fight over creation. We’re supposed to help them in some way, aren’t we? …
I have to admit, I find it impossible to regard my life merely as a means to further that war for one side or the other. …
On the other hand, we should probably be thankful that we are not involved in an all out war. …
Still, I try to avoid dwelling on this. It is disturbing to be constantly faced with the possibility of war breaking out.
I have focused my research on the creation of golems. While this does involve a lot of magic, it also requires a wide range of knowledge in the other fields of science as well.
Admittedly, I am at a bit of a loss as to specifying exactly what it is that we have created here. It is a functional golem and it is working. …
On the other hand, it seems odd and a bit self-preoccupied. It’s almost as if it had some kind of sentience. …
It’s even more of a marvel than I had hoped for! Absolutely fascinating! I will run a series of tests and .. and .. there is so much to be done. …
It seems my work has only just begun!
I came here to study at the academy for a while. …
I grew curious about the northern ruins and for a long time hoped that I’d be allowed to lead an expedition there. …
This came to a halt of course when the criminals and fallen knights took over the ruins. …
Since then I have shifted my focus to creating golems.
The northern ruins are probably the remains of one of the extinct races that preceded humanity during the God Wars …
There are numerous ruins all over the world that tell the silent tales of the rise and the fall of their architects. …
For instance, adventurers discovered subterranean ruins in the Ghostlands. …
The remains of the bonelord civilisation are one of the most notable remnants of such ancient races. …
All over the world you can still see the black pyramids which were typical bonelord structures. Some are still inhabited by a small population of bonelords. …
We can only estimate how many races might been wiped out without a trace. …
However, the ruins in the north are certainly one such relic of the past and that is probably why those renegade knights went there. …
Whoever finds out how to unlock their secrets and make use of them stands to gain considerable wealth and power.
The bonelords are a race fighting extinction. …
Unlike other elder races they have proved themselves to be more resilient, but as far as I can tell, they are only postponing the inevitable. …

How ironical it is that the bonelords refuse to admit that they are on the brink of extinction. You would have thought that their skills in necromancy would have given them some insight into their situation.
Necromancy is referred to as one of the dark arts. Even from a scientific point of view, I can’t deny that this holds a grain of truth. …
Through dabbling with necromancy, one is exposed to certain unhealthy thoughts that can easily corrupt a man. …
So I only study the theory behind the creation of necromantic golems. …
It is an interesting topic but, as I said, it requires some questionable assumptions and a willingness to cross certain boundaries a human shouldn’t ever cross for his own good.
In my opinion, Thais is far too political. All that kingdom and empire stuff serves to entertain the upper classes. …
It doesn’t change anything for the common man and is all about accumulating power and wealth for the powerful and wealthy
The academy holds a wealth of knowledge in many fields. Unfortunately, magic has become far too important in my opinion. …
It’s a pity that other fields are shunned by researchers. …
It makes it quite hard for anyone interested in different fields of science to find appropriate reference material. …
The magicians who lock themselves up in ivory towers, far removed from the ordinary people, is an apt metaphor for how distanced magic has become from everyday life. …
I think a breakthrough coming from the area of independent research might serve as a wake up call for the academy’s board.
Because elves look similar to humans, it is easy to forget that they are completely different. …
They are their own race with their own morals and values. …
Most misunderstandings between humans and elves arise from the fact that humans just assume that elves think like themselves. …
However, the elves are not a scientifically inclined people, so there is little in their culture that would interest me personally. …
Some colleagues of mine at the academy took an interest in elven sorcery though. You might ask there for more information.
My main laboratory in the cellar is stuffed with sophisticated gadgets and gizmos. …
I don’t like having visitors down there and honestly, I don’t find the time to tidy it up, so it’s quite a mess. …
When we manage to assemble a golem I will invite you downstairs for the activation. …
It would be a shame to let you assist me and then exclude you from the moment itself.
I think a king’s job should be to keep things running and not to pursue his own ambitions.
I honestly admire the dwarfs for their craftsmanship. Admittedly, they are a bit tight lipped about their secrets, but who can blame them for that? …
Their technomancers are special though. I would love to converse with them about science and mechanics but as an outsider there is little chance for me to learn anything from them. …
Luckily, there are some rare exceptions to the rule. But that’s a different story.
Humans cannot hope to fully understand the dwarven people. Technomancers are even more enigmatic. However, they are brilliant when it comes to things like physics, mechanics and alchemy. …

Scutty is no exception, quite the contrary. His knowledge of materials and the laws of nature is second to none. I was able to convince him to part with a little of his knowledge. Please ask him to send me everything he is willing to share. …
His knowledge will make the construction of a functional golem so much easier.

He is a genius when it comes to theories. He has written some of the greatest scientific texts I have ever read. Although not all of his suppositions are based on empirical evidence, some of his theories are revolutionary. …
He should be more than happy to have some of his theories put into practice and I have no doubt that he will share his research with me quite willingly.

One day, an undead pigeon arrived with a message from him. It unsettled me that he knew about my research, but for whatever reason he was willing to assist me. I have no reason to distrust his sincerity. …
The information he has sent so far has been valid and has filled some significant gaps in my knowledge. Still, I do wonder what he is up to. Maybe one day I’ll regret having accepted his help.
Boveas is a bit strange, even by our standards. Recently, he has been researching the minotaur civilisation. …

As far as I understood it, he has some information to share with me that would probably fill in a few gaps that I have. I assume he is hiding somewhere in Mintwallin to conduct his research so it might be tricky to find him.

Mintwallin is the city of the minotaurs. It is an underground city, rumoured to be located somewhere in the dungeons north of Thais. Sadly I can’t help you more with finding it. Perhaps you should ask a local for more details.
Cerdras is a druid who is interested in science. Usually druids tend to be more like priests or philosophers but Cerdras has invested his energies in researching life patterns and energy storage. …
Though his magic is different from what I am used to dealing with, I am convinced that some of his information will prove essential for my research.

conversation.Malunga: Greetings. I have only little time to spare, so the conversation will be short. I teach sorcerer spells and buy a few magical ingredients.

The little we know about the extinct civilisation hints about a magically advanced race of humanoids, possibly of elven heritage, that once inhabited those isles until the disaster struck …

It would not surprise me much if some superstitious fools mess around with the chaotic magical currents of this isle. Only the gods may know what harm they could do to themselves and others.

I teach aspiring sorcerers several spells.

Well, ask me for a trade and I’ll show you what I need.
The king’s support of the academy is dwindling. I hope results in my researches will change this significantly.
A typical Venorean. Always around where the money is and constantly looking for a chance to make profit.
The name Morgaroth is mentioned in ancient books quite a few times. He seems to be some higher demon lord who likes to seduce mortals with promises of power to become his worldly minions.

Pirates are a constant pest. As long as their existence does not interfere with my researches, I don’t care much about them.
I have seen them only from afar.
The quara are something that is worth some research. Sadly I lack the time and resources for further investigations.
These isles hold more secrets than those that meet the eye. I am convinced that once a great civilisation prospered here. Some sort of disaster wiped out almost completely any trace of it.
It is a rather uncultivated beverage for the lower classes.

Magic is not available everywhere at the same strength and intensity. There are areas that are dry like a desert, magically spoken, others are rich of magic. At some places magic flows as strong as if there were springs of magic …
At those places the savants build magical centres of great importance. My researches have shown that the chaotic currents of magic must have been more structured once and much stronger than today …
With the right knowledge the civilisation of the past could have worked literally marvellous with those energies …
Even today some use the now chaotic currents of magic to further their evil ends … but … that’s nothing I am supposed to talk about.

This city is too far away to care about.

A rough place with rough people as far as I have heard.
Some young knight who is responsible for the guards and the training of knights.

Psssht! Not that loud! Have you forgotten why there is a codeword?!

<sigh> I knew someone else would claim all the treasure someday. But at least it will be you and not some greedy and selfish person. For a small fee of 200 gold pieces I will sail you to your rendezvous with fate. Do we have a deal?

Uhm, that’s not something a person should talk lightly about. Or think about. Can we change the subject?
Pssht. Not here! Ask me again, when we are back in town.

Thais is of course the crown of our kingdom and the place our hearts will belong to forever.
A fine knight indeed. I am very pleased with his efforts.
The efforts Venore put into this city are admirable. It’s only fair that they gain a certain profit from that.
Superstition! We have real sorcerers and none of them uses such prankish trickery.

conversation.Berenice: Greetings, what can I do for you? If you’re interested in the explorer society, just ask me.

Currently we maintain public bases in Port Hope and Northport. We have also established this humble outpost here.
Our noble society is dedicated to explore the unknown. No location is too remote for our members to travel there …
No beast is too wild to be hunted. No treasure buried too deep to be unearthed …

For an outpost it is quite well organised and comfortable. Uhm … not that a true explorer would give much about comfort.

Pirates are a pain. Constantly we lose supplies and important papers that document our progress here, due to their inroads on our ships. The military really has to eradicate this pest once and for all.
The quara as a race are a phenomenon! There are either different types of quara or they are able to reshape and upgrade their bodies in some way …
To discover the secret magic behind such techniques would be invaluable.
It is astonishing how fertile the soil here seems to be for sugar canes. There is something special about the isles.

Well, there are some plantations in the western part of the isle.
An astonishing place. If you ever want to return there, just ask Captain Max.

Thais is a great city, but not such a centre of learning and knowledge as Edron.

Of course.
Djinns are an extremely interesting topic. Luckily you have just found an expert in djinn lore! To keep matters short, let me only tell you the most notable facts: …
Have you known that there are green and blue djinns? Well, that’s because there are no less than two types of djinns …
<minutes later> Which does mean that some are green and others are blue! …
<several minutes later> I can not stress enough the relevance of the fact that djinns have no need for shoes at all. That leads to astounding facts like …
<another few minutes later> Without shoes you’d think a society would concentrate on some kinds of gloves, but no! …
<after loosing track of time at some point> Which leads to a completely shoeless society that is divided in two colours! …
I see the implication of this fact makes you sweat and your face turn greenish, at last someone who can comprehend the significance of my studies! …
If you ever want to hear more about djinns, just ask me!
This evil wizard once maintained a centre of power here on those isles. After his demise, the Edron academy sealed that place and is extremely secretive about it …
Although it is understandable, it is still an unacceptable hindrance to free research.
The admiral is of little help to us. Instead of providing us troops for protection, he is more concerned that we could draw the attention of imagined enemies on the settlement or destroy something.
That old woman was of some help in cataloguing the local fauna. Still I think she withholds some vital knowledge about local plants.
Chondur … Chondur … I really don’t know where to put that name. Some local celebrity I guess.
This young lady has probably more interest in make-up than in education.

The magic of this isle has its twists. That was the easy part for our mages to find out. The more difficult part will be to figure out why it is that way and what it means for users of magic and for ordinary people …
In the light of this knowledge, this ‘voodoo’ merits some closer research.

Sorry, I don’t sell runes anymore. <coughs> I’m old and have to focus on more important things. Please ask my brother Sigurd next door. <coughs>
Great power brings great responsibility, young one.

Being a sorcerer means to belong to a vocation of great arcane power and responsibility.

conversation.Jagran: I’m Jagran Stonehand, son of fire, from the molten rock fellowship.

Ah, where to begin? After the doom blight and the famine, our troops were in disarray and by no means in suitable strength. … When those lunatics from the Axe of Vengeance fellowship rose to dethrone the emperor, we stood ready to defend our liege. Still, many of those traitors escaped to the mines. … To make matters worse, all kinds of beasts had invaded the mines that were left abandoned while we restored order in Kazordoon. Sounds bad enough to you? … Well, it became worse! When we began to retake the mines from the traitors and the beasts, we encountered another foe, worse than all the others. Have you ever heard of the Lost? Well, you probably have. … They swarmed up from the depths, and if it had not been for our careful advancement and scouting, they might easily have overwhelmed us by surprise and sheer numbers. … We fought many battles, with the traitors and beasts constantly on rampage at our backs. Yet we managed to deal them a crippling blow when Areak killed the creature called Bloodtooth that was leading their armies. … But with that many casualties and enemies on all sides, we had to retreat and regroup. Do you get an idea of our problems now? … The traitors from the Axe of Vengeance, beasts from the depths and the Lost are more than enough to cause a problem. So we can’t spare any men to protect you, and if you venture into the mines you’ll do it at your own risk.

agran: Areak Twobeards was probably the best fighter Kazordoon ever had, and as tough a dwarf as could be. He died after killing the Bloodtooth creature that had led the Lost. … Though he killed the beast, he succumbed to his wounds only a few heartbeats after his enemy fell. His body was rescued and brought to Kazordoon for a proper burial.

I’m sure the gnomes could have done more when the doom blight struck us. But first they raised a quarantine to protect their own mushroom farms and later claimed that their war made it impossible to send considerably more resources. … Still, they did something and sent resources. If their reports about their fights against enemies from below are true, then the amount of help might be deemed acceptable. … Most importantly, they provided us with mushrooms that were resistant to the blight. I have to admit that they are more advanced in mushroom cultivation than we are. I hate to admit that we have been too caught up with traditions; it made us vulnerable.
Who cares about elves? I certainly don’t!

It was like nothing we had ever seen before, and it was huge. First we thought it was some kind of war-beast, but it was frequently seen behind the lines, and rarely engaged in combat. … Later, it became more and more obvious it was the driving force behind the attacks. Areak Twobeards led the assault that broke through the lines of the lost, and confronted the beast. … After his death, the attacks lost in frequency, ferocity and strategic planning.

We will survive as we have countless times before. We are dwarfs and we will boldly face any challenge that fate might throw at us. … We are more than capable to handle our affairs and even lead our people through desperate times without a doubt.

There are many creatures in the mines that came from the depths of the earth after the earthquakes. All kinds of critters are crawling, hunting and breeding in the mines now, as we had to reduce our military presence to key areas. … Even most of the drilling rotworms have gone wild again while left unattended.

Parts of the mines are unstable or collapsed. Others are now connected to natural caves that lead to totally unknown regions of the depths. Given that this brought us the doom blight, it is hard to say what other evils might have crept into the mines.

The mines have always been an unorganized mass of tunnels, for dwarfen standards. But we follow instinct and experience when looking for promising new ore veins, and families, fellowships or trusts frequently dug in competition with each other. … To foreigners, this may seem somewhat odd, but to us dwarfs, it seems natural and necessary.

The Thaians are an arrogant and ignorant bunch. At least they had some honour and sent some resources when the famine struck us. Still, many dwarfs lay part of the blame on humans for all that has happened.
Those Venoreans are hyenas that tried to bleed our people to death when the doom blight struck our mushroom fields. The prices and rights they demanded in exchange were outrageous. …
Sadly, they often got their way due to the desperate situation. But on that matter, the last word has not yet been spoken, and dwarfs have a good memory.
Carlin, with its association with the elves, was never deemed trustworthy in the past. Given the strained relationship with Thais, we should perhaps reconsider this.
You can hardly call it a city. All those trees and bushes, crawling insects everywhere, and the dirt! Just the thought of it gives me shivers.

Kazordoon has seen worse times than this one in its history … The recent earthquakes have done little harm, although combined with the threats that arose, it has been a wake-up call for certain factions; and now we are slightly changing things to be better prepared for threats and to handle certain things … Admittedly, we have rested for too long on the accomplishments of our forefathers who had built Kazordoon. We were doing the ancestors a disservice by not adding more of our own ideas.

The big old one has seen worse earthquakes then the most recent ones. Even the mines weathered them quite well. Our mountain home shrugged them off with little notice at all. … Legends, old even by dwarfen standards, mention earthquakes that changed the face of the surrounding lands but left the big old one unimpressed. … It stands for protection and toughness and is more than just a home to us dwarfs, but a symbol for all that dwarfs stand and fight for. The big old one is our heart and philosophy.
We will not forget that human traders profited from the doom-blight that plagued our people. Their prices for food were an insult to all dwarfs. And for all that I heard, they tried to do worse.

After their failed rebellion, they gave up even the pretense of legitimacy. They bolster their dwindling ranks with outcasts and criminals, and rumor has it that they welcome any dwarf into their ranks, regardless of the crimes he committed.

conversation.Melfar: Just great, another disturbance. Just what I need.
Those good-for-nothing horned monkeys have no better idea than to assault our workers and ruin our mining efforts. Each dead one is a step forward.
What do you mean, you haven’t seen any?? They’re hard to overlook, big and furry. Something must be wrong with your eyes.
Well, if you can find a giant beaver that’s enormous enough for you to jump on, fat human, you’re welcome to compete with us.
Ah, speak no more! I know you want to participate in the beaver rodeo this year! Well, I have some more bait to sell, just ask me for a trade.
We mine ore and crystals in the mines around here. On a good day, we even find gold. Now, don’t get that greedy look! Stay out of there!
I’m the master of supplies for the imperial mining guild. And as such, as you might have guessed, I am a very busy dwarf, so speak up and speak quickly.
Well, supplies like tools, food or wood.
Unless you’re on a mission, I don’t know why I should help you acquiring wood. Or what are you suggesting??
Yep! That’s us. You’re a smart one.
Pah! Speak no more of them treehuggers.
I’m Melfar Rockdriller, master of supplies.
I don’t think I have anything you could need. <scratches head> But if you’ve slain some of them nasty minotaurs – we could definitely use some of their old stuff, especially their horns.

conversation.Dronk: Mh, oh? It looks like YOU WANT to help, well then…?
Dwarfs need coal for all kind of things, most prominently for blacksmithing. So coal is always rare but we need it to run that machine over there.
I hope you are willing to donate some black gold so we can get that pump pumping.
If it weren’t for us dwarfs, the world would have already been overrun by monsters of all kinds.
Well, Groam is a friend. Groam and I already had that pestering pool all drained, but that didn’t last long. SUDDENLY, we heard voices from down there, VOICES my friend. …
We didn’t know what to do, so we started searching the mud. AND THEN, I had that sudden urge to just leave that place. …
PROBLEM IS, when I turned around to ask Groam about it, he just said something about an entrance and then he disappeared. …
So my buddy already went down there, but he did not return. Eventually the water came back and the voices stopped.
I think humans are a bit whimsical but mostly they are alright.
The city is a marvel to behold and unconquered in centuries!
I don’t understand the technomancers magic completely, but using coal on one of the three pumps down here will drain the water in the pool at the end of the tunnel. …
PROBLEM IS, when the water is drained, something seems to ‘awake’. …
Hey stop looking like that, I know it’s true, I don’t make this up. I HEARD THEM. Alright, I heard them.
I’m Dronk Coaljuggler, Son of Fire, from the Savage Axes fellowship.

Somehow the water of the pool will return after some time, I don’t know why. Maybe it has to do with ‘something’ down there. It makes the water rise… ah I don’t know. I just want my buddy Groam to be ok.
As you might have noticed, the tunnel here is filled with water. We got the machines from the technomancers to pump the water out but our resources on coals are quite thin. …
Most coal is used for blacksmithing and something as unimportant as an inaccessible tunnel is not deemed worthy of our black gold you know. …
We KNOW it is no ordinary tunnel system down there though but we found some kind of ruins down there. PROBLEM IS, we had no spare time for exploring before the water drove us out. …
Now I really would love to get the machines running but first we have to gather enough coal to make them work.
Spooky guys but they have their use, as you can see when looking at that machine over there.

The rotworm driven tunnels have to be reworked by dwarven miners before we can use them safely. They seem a bit erratic to the untrained eye but the worms are trained to dig towards the richest deposits of ore. …
So our tunnels are exceptionally safe but sometimes even we run into problems.
Well, they are clearly… hey, wait – stop looking like that. They are there, they are talking to me. Surely you must hear them, too… clearly now… just now… or not?!
Ah by any chance, did you see… ah nothing, bye then.
I’m responsible to oversee the security and integrity of the mine tunnels. …
Ah right, and you can help me out here if you want. PROBLEM IS, you probably don’t even know what you are doing here. …
See the pumps there? And the pool of water over there?
Good, because that is part of the problem. AND THE PROBLEM IS, while these pumps are able to drain the water out of the pond over there, they only work for a limited time. …
They run on *coal* you see, COAL. And that’s the one thing I just don’t have down here right now. …
Yeah I know that I could mine some more or just loot some creature’s corpse but I can’t leave just yet. …
Still, even with that pool drained, I still need to find Groam and I surely won’t leave without him.
I’m responsible to oversee the security and integrity of the mine tunnels. …
Ah right, and you can help me out here if you want. PROBLEM IS, you probably don’t even know what you are doing here. …
See the pumps there? And the pool of water over there?
Come on. Look closer!

conversation.Emperor Kruzak: Hiho, may fire and earth bless you, my child. Are you looking for a promotion?
Do you want to be promoted in your vocation for 20000 gold?
Well, I’m Emperor Kruzak Dustbeard, son of Fire and Earth, second only to the gods, jawoll.
Well, we honour Father Earth and Mother Fire. Some of us even follow the teachings of additional gods.
Well, I’m the emperor of the dwarfs. It’s my duty to protect my folk and to see that justice is done.
Well, go and see the wonders of our cities for yourself.
It is said that he lives on a small island near Edron. Maybe the people there know more about him.
Well, more than 150 years ago, my father lost his beard overnight. Thereupon, he resigned from his leadership after hundreds of years of supreme ruling.
<sigh> Well, it saddens me to see what can become of a dwarf. They are truly lost. They are not ours any more, even if their ancestors once might have been. …
Their dwarfish traits though make them fearsome fighters and the number in which their masters have bred them makes them a threat for anyone. …
The worst thing is, if their masters did not seemingly consider the gnomes their major enemies, we would probably face even fiercer attacks. …

It took our entire might to stop their last invasion force. Only when their leader Bloodtooth, a horrible thing that none of our experienced veterans had ever encountered before, was cut down, was the assault stopped. …

Now the Lost are roaming the mines, and are still numerous and powerful enough to pose a threat. Meanwhile, we are regrouping and reorganizing in the hopes that we will be better prepared when the time of another assault comes.
Well, we use all stocked resources of finest metal to craft weapons and armor, we train new warriors and spellcasters every day. …
We give battle training to each citizen to enable them to better defend themselves and to form militia units in case of emergency. And we call in old favours and allies.
Well, all dwarfs could be considered citizens. We are brothers and sisters in fire and earth.
Well, after some centuries I stopped to worry about time.
Well, you claim there is another dwarven city called Beregar? Could that be the city of the ancient tribe?!?
Well, there is an old poem that is known by every dwarven child. It tells a story about the God Wars and the early years of Tibia. There have been two big dwarven tribes, but then a conflict arose. …

This conflict caused one of the tribes to leave their birthplace and to find themselves a new home. Not in my wildest dreams I would have believed that this poem could contain some truth. You should try to find it.
Well, our race is very hot-blooded, bullheaded, and also proud. The real cause is unknown but I can imagine how it happened.

Well, it must have been written by someone of the Kazordoon tribe as there hasn’t been any contact to the other tribe since the day we parted. I doubt you’ll find a written copy of it here as it has been passed on by word of mouth. …
Maybe you find someone who tells you the poem. I for myself don’t have time to tell you a children’s poem. By the beard of my father, I’m the emperor, jawoll!
Well, like all dwarfs we worship earth and fire. As you know, our tribe is closer connected to the element of earth. It is said that the other tribe prefers the element of fire.
WAAAH! Don’t mention that beast! He was after the bones of our ancestors last time King Tibianus visited us!
Well, the gods handed the lands over to the younger races, but my people will leave this world in dignity.
Well, we keep peace with Carlin and Thais.
Well, it’s a colony of this human king.
Well, they are not as bad as one might think.
Well, you’d better ask the general.
Well, we are prepared even for him.
Well, well, well, the god blade. A myth? Perhaps. Even in my youth, it was only a legend.
Well, I’m fine, the last centuries have been good to me, jawoll.
Well, if you walk through the world with open eyes, you will see quests without asking.
Well, our mines have been invaded by a basilisk. We trapped him with a cave-in. The hero who brings me the body of this beast will get a great reward. …
But of course after the blight we have other problems down there, like the lost and the renegades.
Well, the blight was a great disaster. It hit us completely unprepared. …

Given the severity of the disaster, we can be glad we handled it that well. Still, it weakened our defences, and by chance or sinister plans our enemies took it as an opportunity to hit us even harder. …
In the midst of recovering from the blight and relocating resources, the trouble in the mines began. First with rampaging creatures and then came the Lost. …
With resources bound there, even here in Kazordoon an enemy rose his ugly head … and this head wore a dwarfen beard. Our own people, lead by the Axe of Vengeance fellowship.
Well, the Axes of Vengeance were troublemakers even when they were few. Their reckless ways and boasting sadly impressed a lot of the young and easily gullible. …
Stories of their mostly made-up exploits and lies lured some into their embrace, but it was not until the blight that they became popular and a threat thanks to their leader, Jarok Bilespit.

Well, Jarok Bilespit was a mercenary. He did many questionable things for money. Especially dealing with non-dwarfs, although he usually was the first to express their disgust for them, when not taking their money, of course. …

He gathered around him a number of drunkards and bullies of the worst sort, and founded the Axes of Vengeance fellowship, which was rather his private gang than a true fellowship. … Emperor Kruzak: They were usually travelling on contract, doing questionable missions and only returned to Kazordoon to boast about their made-up exploits and to spend their ill-begotten money with both hands. …
This impressed certain people and gained him an undeserved reputation as a daring hero. …

Though no week they were in town passed without one of them getting imprisoned for brawls, threats and destruction of property, especially younger dwarfs thought it would be cool to be one of them, and if not respected, then at least be feared. …

When the blight struck, his easy explanations and pointless accusations stroke a cord in the minds of several individuals. I admit we did not see this coming and let him spread his phrases in the city. …
We had other things to do and did not want more unrest by arresting some popular figure. With our attention elsewhere, Bilespit took advantage of the desperate and lured them into his ranks. …
He was never the subtle type though, so it became quite clear what unspeakable treason he planed. …

When he led his bunch of mercenaries and several drunks as some kind of meat-shield to dethrone me, we were prepared. We planned to take Bilespit down first to minimize casualties, but things got out of hand and there were many deaths on both sides. …

With the order to keep presumably innocent casualties low, my guards fought very restricted, which could have led to their losing the battle. So we had to change orders to reduce our own casualties, and the fight turned very bloody and nasty. …
Rumours spread through the city and others who thought they sympathized with Bilespit’s cause joined the battles. …
Still, we tried to keep casualties low; and as soon as we took certain strategic positions and gained the upper hand, most of the rebellious forces escaped. …
Now they are hiding in the mine: Most of those mines are old and depleted of ore. They are overrun by all sorts of creatures such as the Lost. …

So it made not much sense to send in troops that could not efficiently use their numbers and combat training in brawls within winding and narrow tunnels. We had to sent in troops to fight the advancing lost, though.
Well, our people love gold, that’s common knowledge.
Well, dwarven knights are feared by our enemies in the whole world.
Well, we have almost no druids in our town. If need arises, we can ask for them in Carlin.
Well, we have some crossbowmen in our army but rely more on our knights.
Well, I don’t want to talk about my age.
Well, my subjects maintain many fine shops. Go and have a look at their wares.
Well, we don’t fear them. They seem more occupied with the humans anyway.
Well, Durin is one of the celestial paladins, messenger of the gods. He’s the protector of the dwarven race.
Well, justice is a difficult thing. Can one be just to everybody at once, and if not, to whom should he be just?
Well, go and buy some in the city.
Well, there are a lot of dungeons in Tibia, waiting to be explored by the daring ones.
Well, some of the greatest heroes of all times have been dwarfs.
Well, the sorcerers are followers of the elemental powers.
Well, it’s up to the younger ones to slay the beasts that roam the lands and the tunnels.
Well, only a dead enemy is a good enemy.
Well, I don’t think our southern allies have agents in our town.
Well, we aren’t poor, and we have ways to defend our wealth.
Well, our people need no castle, our home IS a fortress.
Well, chaos is the ancient enemy. Dwarfs bring order to the world and give things shape. We are enemies of chaos.
Well, there are some in our city. Go and visit them.
Well, I’m too old to care about gossip anymore.
Well, the highest paladin is a woman that deserves respect. I’ve admired most Elanes I met in my life.
Well, good and evil will fight each other for all eternity.
Well, I’m the emperor of the dwarfs and the oldest living dwarf, jawoll!
Well, we have two guilds in our town, the knight and the sorcerer one.
Well, I am too busy to help you, but feel free to ask around.
Well, isn’t that the leader of the Carlin paladins?
Well, order is of great importance. Life has to follow rules, and so do we.
Well, that’s an trustworthy ally of dwarfs.
Well, isn’t it reward enough to talk to the emperor of all dwarfs?
Well, what do you expect a king to sell?
Well, that’s Carlin’s highest knight, isn’t she? Not too bad as fighter for a big one.
Farewell, Player, my child!

conversation.Gnomercy: Hi there! I'm ready to brief you with tactical advice.

With your help and efforts we finally cornered what we think is one of 'those below'! For all you have done and endured you are granted the privilege to be one of the first to fight the true enemy. ...
For all we know your successes have brought some unrest to our enemies and they sent one of their observers to punish their slaves and force them to more fierce attacks. ...

This is our chance to deal the enemy the first blow in this conflict. With reinforcements from Gnomehome we are attacking the troops of the enemy and binding a great deal of their forces in battle. ...
Now it is up to you to fight your way to the heart of the enemy's defences and kill the observer. ...

Our first tries were met with no success though. The observer has brought with him one of his creatures or lieutenants, the lost call the thing Versperoth. I am not sure if it is a name or a race. ...
However Versperoth itself is protected by hoards of minions. Sometimes this thing will withdraw into the ground and let all hell loose in form of its' slaves. ...
You'd better be finished with them before Versperoth re-emerges. ...
Only when you manage to kill Versperoth, will you be able to enter the portal behind him and face the true evil of the observer. ...
Go and unleash your inner gnome! Vanquish the source of evil.

The life-giving earth protects us, feeds us and takes us home once we have died.
